texts.en: Rita G. lives in Thecho, Lalitpur with her mother-in-law, her husband, and her daughter, a primary school student. Her husband, Radesh G., opened his computer institute eight years ago, teaching basic computer and graphic design courses. His five computers at the institute are  not enough to meet student demand, so Rita is requesting her sixth loan to buy another computer to help her husband. This will also help to provide a better income for her family and improve their standard of living.

loans.use: to buy computers for her husband's work

loans.name: Christine

texts.en:
Christine N. is 16 years old and lives in the town of Bulenga in the Kampala central region of Uganda. She is married and has no children. Christine has a business selling charcoal, which she has had for 3 years. She also has a second business selling food and fruits.

To help expand her business, Christine has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. This loan will be used to purchase more food and charcoal for resale. With the help of this loan from BRAC, Christine hopes to generate greater profits and buy food. In the future, Christine hopes to go back to school and complete her studies.  

Christine is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future with instruction on how to save money.

loans.use: to purchase more food and charcoal for resale.

loans.name: Herma

texts.en:
Herma, 38 years old, lives in Banga, South Cotabato with her family. She is married and has two children aged 15 and 3.

Herma is a farmer. She grows rice, corn and vegetables. She sells her harvest to the market. Herma has a cow that helps till her land. Herma always does her best for her farm to be productive.

This loan will be used to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs. In the future, she hopes to see her children succeed in life.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs

loans.name: Jessie

texts.en:
Jessie is 36 years old and is still single. He lives in Banga, South Cotabato. 

Jessie has been in the business of raising hogs for two years. He plans to use his loan to purchase feed and vitamins. He will also buy materials to expand his piggery. Each month, Jessie earns 3,000 PHP from raising hogs.

loans.use: to purchase feed, vitamins and materials for piggery expansion

loans.name: Surriya's Group

texts.en:
Surriya comes from Faisalabad which is a big city located in Punjab, Pakistan and known for its textile industry. She has been living there in the area of Ghulamabad with her family in a 2-room brick house for the past 25 years. She is 57 years old, and it is difficult for her to support her family financially by doing any work at this older age, but she performs her household activities very responsibly and efficiently. 

She is the mother of five sons. Her two elder sons left off their education at an early age and started work to help support the family. Her eldest son operates a motor workshop while the second one makes gloves. The next two sons operate a donkey cart and her youngest son is getting a religious education.
 
Her husband's name is M. A. and he is involved in a food-selling business. He runs a small restaurant where he offers Punjabi food items like "Nan chanay" (made with chick peas and served with bread). 

Surriya has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her eldest son who wants to improve his motor workshop business. Using the loan, he will purchase the latest repair tools to provide better quality service to his clients. Surriya is hopeful that her son’s 10 years of experience will help him establish his business after the loan investment and she will be able to marry him off in the near future. 

She is a new loan applicant and this is her first loan application to Asasah. 

`Note: In the photo, the lady raising her hand is Surriya.

loans.use: To buy the latest repair tools for her son's motor workshop business.

loans.name: Juvy

texts.en:
Juvy is 42 years old and is a married woman with four children. Her oldest child is 23 years old. 

Juvy is a farmer working in Banga, South Cotabato. She has been growing corn and fruit for 16 years. Juvy works hard to improve her business and provide for her family.

This loan will be used to purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs

loans.name: Leonida

texts.en:
Leonida is a farmer who lives in Banga, South Cotabato with her family. She is 55 years old and married. Leonida grows rice and corn crops and then sells her harvest to the market. She also owns and manages a sari-sari store where she sells items like canned goods and noodles.

Leonida's loan will be used to purchase farm inputs and additional merchandise to sell.

loans.use: to purchase farm inputs and additional merchandise to sell

loans.name: Marlon

texts.en:
Marlon is a farmer from the town of Banga, South Cotabato. He is 42 years old and still single. Marlon grows rice and sells his harvest to the market. He also raises pigs in his backyard. Marlon works hard to improve his businesses. 

Marlon's loan will be used to purchase feed, fertilizers and other farm inputs.

loans.use: to purchase feed, fertilizers and other farm inputs

loans.name: Mary Ann

texts.en:
Mary Ann, 36 years old, is a married woman who lives in the town of Banga, South Cotabato. She has two children ages 11 and 15.

Mary Ann is engaged in farming and retail businesses. She has been growing corn crops for three years and earns 2,000 PHP from this business. She also sells soft drinks to the people in her community. Mary Ann works hard to provide for her family.

This loan will be used to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs

loans.name: Mary Jane

texts.en:
Mary Jane is a married woman with two children who are 19 and 16 years old. They live in the town of Banga, South Cotabato.

Mary Jane is engaged in farming and hog-raising businesses. She grows rice and corn crops and then sells her harvest to the market. She also raises pigs for fattening and sale. Mary Jane hopes that her farm will always be productive and her piggery will grow.

This loan will be used to purchase seeds, fertilizers and feed.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, fertilizers and feed

loans.name: Wilmel

texts.en:
Wilmel is 23 years old and married. She has two children aged four and one. Her husband works as a farmer.

Wilmel is in the business of raising hogs. Each month, she earns 4,000 PHP by doing the hog-raising business. Wilmel also grows papayas and sells the fruit to the market. Wilmel plans to use her loan to purchase feed, vitamins and other supplies.

Wilmel wishes for her business to succeed.

loans.use: to purchase feed, vitamins and other supplies

loans.name: Sorie I.'s Group

texts.en:
Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT) is pleased to present to you teachers of the DEC Sinkunia Primary School in Kabala, a town in northern Sierra Leone. This institution was founded in 1951 by the District Education Council to promote education in the district. The institution is staffed with 12 teachers and has an enrollment of 586 pupils.

This is the first loan that DEC Primary School Sinkunia is requesting from Kiva through SMT. With the help of this loan, some of these teachers will start small businesses. Some will invest their loans in an already existing business. Others will buy pieces of furniture and house-building materials, pay school fees for their children, and so on. At the end of each month, the school’s burser is directly responsible for deducting the loan repayments out of their monthly salaries and pays SMT/Kiva on their behalf.

Sorie I. S., the leader of this group of teachers, was born in Koinadugu District, northern Sierra Leone. He is married to a trader and has seven children, two of whom are in primary school, three in secondary school and two in college. Sorie, who has 28 years of experience in the teaching profession, has requested a loan of SLL 1,000,000 in order to purchase a piece of land for the future construction of a family house.

loans.use: to purchase a piece of land for the future construction of a family house.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy local produce like rice, palm-oil, etc., at wholesale

loans.name: One Word Iii Group

texts.en:
Meet members of the “One Word III” group from Kabala, a town in northern Sierra Leone. They are all local entrepreneurs who have come to SMT, a partner of Kiva, to apply for a loan of SLL 500,000 for each. With the help of this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and consequently improve on their living conditions. 

Fatu M. is the leader of this group. The wife and mother of two children who attend primary school, was born in northern Sierra Leone. She has been a businesswoman for six years. She has come to SMT/Kiva lenders to ask for this loan in order to expand her business inventory. She sells plastic bowls, plastic buckets, plastic plates, plastic baskets, etc.

loans.use: to buy plastic bowls, plastic buckets, plastic plates, plastic baskets, etc., in large quantities to resell

loans.name: Isatu

texts.en:
Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT), a partner of Kiva in Makeni, northern Sierra Leone, is very pleased to present to you Isatu B., a small scale entrepreneur who has come to SMT/Kiva lenders to ask for a loan of SLL 5,000,000 in order to invest in her business. 

Isatu sells assorted goods, both in wholesale and in retail. She sells items such as sugar, salt, margi (used to give sauce a sweet taste), onions, vegetable oil, and so on. She has been a businesswoman for eight years in the township of Kabala, in northern Sierra Leone.

A wife and a mother of two children who attend primary school and one child who attends secondary school, the 25-year-old was born in Magburaka town, but now lives and sells in Kabala town. Isatu has requested this loan in order to buy the above mentioned items in large quantities to add to her business.

loans.use: to buy sugar, salt, margi (used to give sauce a sweet taste), onions, vegetable oil, and so on, in large quantities to resell

loans.name: Word Group

texts.en:
Meet members of the “Word” group from Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. They are all local entrepreneurs who have come to SMT, a partner of Kiva, to apply for a loan of SLL 800,000 for each. With the help of this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and consequently improve on their living conditions. 

Hawa S. is the leader of this group. The 40-year-old is married to a farmer and they have four children. Hawa has been a businesswoman for 11 years. She sells margi (used to give sauce a sweet taste), cooking oil, salt, etc. With her share of this loan, she will buy the above mentioned items at wholesale to add to her business.

loans.use: to buy margi (used to give sauce a sweet taste), cooking oil, salt, etc., at wholesale

loans.name: Blessings Group

texts.en:
Mama S. is the leader of this group of entrepreneurs. Mama was born in Kabala, a town in northern Sierra Leone. She is married to a businessman and the couple has five children – two in primary school and three in college. Mama sells bananas, palm-oil (the country’s favorite cooking oil), rice, groundnuts, millets, etc. She has been a businesswoman for 15 years. 

With the help of this loan, Mama and her group members will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and consequently improve on their living conditions. Mama will use her share of the loan (SLL 500,000) to buy the above mentioned items at wholesale to add to her business.

loans.use: to buy palm-oil, rice, groundnuts, millets, etc., at wholesale to add to her business

loans.name: Fatmata

texts.en:
Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT), a partner of Kiva in Makeni, northern Sierra Leone, is very pleased to present to you Fatmata K., a small scale entrepreneur who has come to SMT/Kiva lenders to seek for a loan of SLL 5,000,000 in order to invest in her business. 

A wife and a mother of three children – two in primary school and one in secondary school – the 42-year-old was born in one of the villages make up Sanda, but she now lives and sells in Kabala town. Fatmata sells market food stuffs like fish, rice, groundnuts, soap, etc. She has been doing this business for 28 years. 

Fatmata has requested this loan in order to increase her business inventory. With this loan, she estimates buying bags of caustic soda for the production of a large quantity of soap, five bags of husk rice, two bags of cleaned rice, and ten bags of ground-nuts.

loans.use: to buy bags of caustic soda, a large quantity of soap, five bags of husk rice, two bags of cleaned rice, and ten bags of ground-nuts in order to increase her inventory

loans.name: Edward S.'s Group

texts.en:
Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT), a partner of Kiva in Makeni, northern Sierra Leone, is pleased to present to you teachers of the DEC Kamasiki Primary School, from Kamasiki village, near Makeni. DEC Primary School was founded in 1974 by the Bombali District Council to educate the pupils of the Chiefdom. DEC Primary School Kamasiki has seven teachers and 390 pupils. 

This is the first loan that this school has applied for from SMT/Kiva lenders. Edward S. C. is the leader of this group of teachers. The 53-year-old Edward was born in a village called Kamaron. He is married and has 14 children – 11 of whom are attending school. With his share of this loan, Mr. C. will buy house building materials to complete the construction of his house.

loans.use: to buy house building materials to complete the construction of his house

loans.name: Cristo Salvador Group

texts.es: La Sra. Rosalinda es casada y tiene 3 hijos, Rosalinda es integrante D. la alcancía comunal “Cristo Salvador ” grupo conformado por 9 socios que se dedican a actividades D. comercio, Rosalinda  alquila mototaxi  desD. hace 5 años este  trabajo surge a raíz D. que ella quería conseguir  mejores  ingresos y   darle trabajo a mucha gente y es así que  gracias  a su esfuerzo y dedicación se ha comprado muebles, equipo D. sonido, escritorio , y sus hijos tienen una buena educación y sobre todo darles una buena calidad D. vida a sus hijos, por que sin ellos no hubiera tenido la fuerza para conseguir todo lo que hoy en día tiene. El préstamo que  se le otorgo fue para  darle mantenimiento  a sus motos. Sabemos que Rosalinda  cumplirá sus metas con mucho trabajo y esfuerzo y que los préstamos D. Edaprospo la ayudaran.
texts.en: Mrs. Rosalinda is married and has three children. She is a member of the “Cristo Salvador” (Christ the Savior) Community Bank. This group is maD. up of nine members that are businesspeople. Rosalinda rents motor-taxis. In the past five years this business has grown so much that Rosalinda has increased her earnings and provided work for a lot of people. Thanks to her dedication and effort she has purchased furniture, sound equipment and a desk. Her children have had a good education. Above everything, these earnings have improved the quality of life for her children. If it weren’t for her efforts, they wouldn’t have everything that they have today. The loan that she is requesting will be used for motor-taxi maintenance. We know that Rosalinda reaches her goals through much work and effort and this loan from Edaprospo will help her.

loans.use: to maintain a motor-taxi.

loans.name: Santa Rosa De Lima Group

texts.es: La Sra. Juana es casada y tiene 8 hijos, Juana  es integrante de la alcancía comunal “Santa Rosa de Lima ” grupo conformado por  8 socios que se dedican a actividades de comercio, Juana se dedica  a la venta de ropa en un puesto en el mercado desde hace 8 años, este  trabajo surge a raíz de que ella quería conseguir  mejores ingresos   y tener su propia casa, es así que gracias a su esfuerzo y dedicación a conseguido  mejores ingresos, se compro su terreno donde hoy en día vive con su familia y tienen una mejor calidad de vida Juana nos cuenta que nada fue fácil pero trabajo muy duro para tener lo que hoy en día tiene. El préstamo que  se le otorgo fue para  comprar mercadería y ampliar su negocio. Sabemos que Juana   cumplirá sus metas con mucho trabajo y esfuerzo y que los préstamos de Edaprospo la ayudaran.
texts.en: Mrs. Juana is married and has eight children. She is a member of the “Santa Rosa de Lima” Community Bank, a group with eight members that are all businesspeople. For the past eight years Juana has sold clothes from a booth in the market. This work meets the needs of what she wants to achieve, a good income and the ability to buy a house. Thanks to her efforts and dedication, she has good earnings and she bought a house where her family is currently living. They have a better quality of life. Juana told us that nothing is easy but she worked very hard to have the things she has today. With the loan that she is requesting she will buy merchandise and thereby expand her business. We know that Juana meets her goals through much work and effort and that this loan from Edaprospo will help her.

loans.use: to buy merchandise.

loans.name: Mujeres Trabajadoras Group

texts.es:
Las mujeres del presente comité son de la Compañia Candia de la ciudad de Caacupe, que dista a 18 km de la oficina regional de la zona.
La presidenta del comité es la Sra. Gloria A., ella se dedica a la elaboración y venta de dulces, vive con su marido que es empleado público y sus hijos que son estudiantes.
La Sra. Gloria es una persona muy trabajadora y sacrificada, elabora sus dulces semanalmente y sale a venderlos por la ciudad de Caacupe y Atyra, sin importar el calor o el frío, ni las lluvias fuertes que a veces vienen, pues su familia es muy pobre y ella necesita del dinero que gana como ingresos de sus ventas diarias.
Gloria y todas sus compañeras están muy agradecidas con la Fundación Paraguaya y Kiva por el apoyo que les brinda para poder seguir aumentando sus ingresos y así mejorar su calidad de vida, por eso se animan a solicitar este crédito, porque saben que pueden contar con la ayuda de los inversionistas con el préstamo financiero.
Gloria, por ejemplo, solicitó el crédito para poder comprar más azúcar y frutas para la realización de los dulces caseros que prepara y para poder adquirir también gas para su garrafa, sin la cual no puede cocinar sus dulces.
texts.en:
The women of this committee are from the Compañia Candia in the city of Caacupe, located 18 km from the regional office in the zone.
Gloria A. is the group’s president and makes and sells candies.  She lives with her husband who is a public employee and her children are students.

Gloria is a very hard working and sacrificing woman.  She makes her candy every week and sells it in the cities of Caacupe and Atyra, regardless of the weather (hot, cold, or hard rain).  Her family is very poor and she needs the money that she earns from her daily sales.

Gloria and all of her cohorts are very grateful to Fundación Paraguaya and to Kiva for the support that they have given to help them increase their incomes and be able to improve their qualities of life.  They were motivated to request this loan because they know that they can count on the lenders’ assistance with the loan.

Gloria, for example, requested her loan to be able to buy more sugar and fruit to make more homemade candy.  She will also get a cylinder of gas, without which she cannot make her candy.

loans.use: to buy supplies and ingredients

loans.name: Santa Rosa Group

texts.es:
El comité de mujeres de nombre Santa Rosa se conformó en fecha 03 de julio del 2008. Con mucho esfuerzo y esmero se encuentran ya en el décimo ciclo, en forma conjunta y solidaria dentro del programa.
Además del trabajo independiente de cada una, también  hacen trabajos en forma conjunta con el fin de contar con un capital dentro del grupo.
Una historia muy conmovedora es la de la Sra. Luciana B., quien se dedica a la artesanía, nos comenta que mediante el crédito y la asesoría recibida de Fundacion Paraguaya durante todos estos años, pudo mejorar bastante su actividad y su administración.
Ella posee varios telares en su domicilio, donde cuenta con gran variedad de productos y tejidos con precios muy accesibles, mediante este negocio la economía de la familia mejoró bastante.
Las actividades que realizan con la Fundación Paraguaya son muy importantes para las miembros de este grupo ya que pudieron desarrollar sus capacidades de trabajo en equipo, además de levantar su autoestima como madres trabajadoras.
texts.en:
This committee of hard working women is called Santa Rosa and was formed on July 3, 2008.  With lots of effort and motivation they are now in their 10th loan cycle, in a very united way within the program.

Aside from their individual work, they also work together to raise funds for the group.

One moving story is that Luciana B., who sells crafts, tells us that the loan and advice she’s been getting all these years from Fundacion Paraguaya, allowed her to greatly improve her business and its management.

She has a number of looms in her home, where she also has a large number of weaved items at good prices.  This business helped her household financial situation improve greatly.

The activities with Fundación Paraguaya are very important for the members of the group, because they were able to develop their training as a team.  It also raised their self esteem as working mothers.
.

loans.use: to buy fabric and supplies

loans.name: Nueva Esperanza Group

texts.es:
El contacto para el inicio del presente comité fue la señora Maria Liz A., ella invitó y organizó a sus amigas para formar parte del programa Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras.
La sra. Maria Liz A. se dedica a la venta de ropas y ahora quiere emprender su venta de cosméticos.
Ella tiene pareja, con quien vive desde hace 16 años, es el señor Ignacio R., quien trabaja en una empresa grande, tienen cuatro hijos estudiantes, tres en la secundaria y una niña de tres años.
La señora Maria Liz solicitó el crédito para la compra de productos que la ayuden a surtir mejor sus negocios (abrigos en general, sábanas, cremas, colonias, y cosméticos).
Ella sueña con abrir un negocio de mercería en el centro de Luque y de esa manera aumentar su ingresos para brindar lo mejor a sus hijos.
Todas las integrantes del comité son mujeres luchadoras y esperanzadas en un mejor vivir, en una mejor calidad de vida para sus familias, por eso acuden a esta institución confiando ciegamente en que conseguirán la ayuda que requieren.
texts.en:
Maria Liz A. was the focal point for beginning this group.  She invited and organized her friends to form the “Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras” (Committee for Entrepreneurial Women).

Maria Liz A. sells clothing and now she wants to begin selling cosmetics.  She’s been married to Ignacio R. for 16 years.  He works for a large company.  They have four children, three in junior high school and one three year old daughter.  Maria Liz requested a loan to buy products that will provide a better assortment in her businesses (coats, sheets, creams, colognes, and cosmetics).

Some day she would like to open a store in downtown Luque and in that way be able to increase her income to provide the best for her children.

All the members of the committee are hard working women hoping for a better quality of life for their families.  They have approached this institution hoping that they will get the assistance that they need.

loans.use: to buy merchandise to stock her business

loans.name: Virgen De La Misericordia Group

texts.es:
Virgen de la  Misericordia se denomina el excelente grupo de mujeres conformado en la ciudad de Ita, gracias a que la actual Directora General, la Sra. Silvia D., contactó con la asesora en una reunión semanal que la misma tenía en la zona, para enterarse de la forma de trabajo que tiene el Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras.
Una vez asesorada acerca del programa logró juntar a 16 mujeres quienes se encuentran trabajando muy a gusto ya en el 4° ciclo.
Todas ellas realizan actividades para recaudar fondos, se ayudan mutuamente para llegar a los objetivos en común que todas tienen dentro del grupo y con la Fundación Paraguaya.
La sra. Silvia se dedica a la venta de carnes, es una actividad que lo viene realizando desde hace varios años, y es el medio mediante el cual mantiene a su familia, como posee mucha clientela la demanda supera su capacidad de abastecimiento, por eso solicita el crédito, para poder comprar más carnes de modo a poder satisfacer las necesidades de sus clientes.
texts.en:
This group of extraordinary women is called “Virgen de Misericordia” (Lady of Mercy) and is located in the city of Ita, thanks to the current manager, Silvia D..  She contacted the advisor at a weekly meeting in the same zone, to find out about the work of the Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras (Committee of Enterprising Women).

Once she got advice, she was able to bring 16 women together and they are all now comfortably working on their fourth cycle.

All of them do different things to gather funds to mutually help one another to reach their common goals within the group and with Fundación Paraguaya.  Silvia sells meat and has been doing so for several years.  She supports her family this way, but since she has many customers, the demand is greater than supply, so she is asking for this loan to be able to buy more meat to satisfy her customer demand.

loans.use: to buy more meat for her butcher shop

loans.name: Mujeres Exitosas Group

texts.es:
Este Comité se formó gracias a la Señora María Esther Q. R., domiciliada en la cuidad de Villarrica, ella invitó a sus amigas y encantadas aceptaron conformar el Comité de Mujeres Rurales nombrando al Comité "Mujeres Exitosas".
Las integrantes del comité se dedican a la artesanía, que es un trabajo que heredaron de sus padres y va pasando de generación en generación.
Ellas confeccionan hermosas prendas de vestir como ser: camisas, manteles, y todo tipo de bordados en ao poi. También se dedican al comercio de esas artesanías.
Este grupo es un grupo muy unido y solidario, ya que las señoras constantemente hacen actividades para ayudarse entre todas.
Con la ayuda que le ofreció la Fundación Paraguaya, este comité logró mejorar sus ingresos ya que solicitaron un crédito para invertir en sus negocios, para de esta forma mejorar sus condiciones de vida y la de su familia.
Como es el caso de la sra. María Esther, quien es la que más antigüedad tiene en el rubro de la artesanía y lo hace solamente para mejorar el nivel de vida de sus hijos, más que la de si misma, ella es una mujer emprendedora y muy sacrificada que tiene la esperanza en que Kiva la ayudará.
texts.en:
This committee was formed thanks to María Esther Q. R. who lives in Villarrica.  She invited her friends to form the Committee of Rural Women called “Mujeres Exitosas” (Successful Woman).

The members of the committee are artists, an art that they learned from their parents, passed from generation to generation.

They make beautiful clothing like shirts, aprons, and all types of embroidery in ao poi.  They also sell these items.  This group is very united and the women constantly work together to help one another.

With the help of Fundación Paraguaya, the members of this committee were able to improve their incomes after they requested a loan with which to invest in their businesses.  This allowed them to improve their families’ living conditions, as is the case for María Esther, who has been an artist the longest and does it only to improve the quality of life for her children as well as for herself.  She is an enterprising woman who makes lots of sacrifices and hopes that Kiva will help her.

loans.use: to buy arts and crafts supplies

loans.name: Mujeres De Hierro Group

texts.es:
El comité se denomina Mujeres de Hierro, es un grupo unido que se encuentra en la ciudad de San Lorenzo, son mujeres que desean salir de la pobreza con sacrificio y mucho esmero.
Han trabajado arduamente para tener una caja chica de la cual todas dependen en los momentos difíciles, se ayudan mutuamente para que puedan crecer todas al mismo tiempo en el aspecto económico.
La sra. Maria Luisa posee un puesto de venta de comidas, allí ofrece sus mejores productos a la comunidad y en especial a aquello que trabajan y no llegan a sus casas para la hora de la comida, entonces ella prepara con mucha dedicación estos alimentos y los vende a precios muy accesibles para todas las personas.
Ella solicita el crédito para poder comprar bebidas, panificados, fideos, arroz, cereales, harina, aceite, carnes y verduras, de modo a ofrecer en mayores cantidades sus comidas y así pueda algún día aumentar el tamaño de su negocio.
texts.en:
This group is called “Women of Iron” and is a united group located in San Lorenzo.  The group is made up of women who want to break free from poverty through sacrifice and hard work.  The members have worked arduously to build a small reserve that they each depend on during difficult times.  They mutually support one another so that they can all grow financially together.

Maria Luisa has a food stall where she offers her best products to the community, especially to the workers who don’t have time to go home at lunchtime.  She prepares the food with great care and sells it at affordable prices.

She is asking for this loan so she can buy drinks, bread, noodles, rice, cereals, flour, cooking oil, meats, and vegetables in quantity, so that she can offer greater amounts of  food and someday be able to grow her business.
.

loans.use: to buy ingredients

loans.name: Mujeres En Progreso Group

texts.es:
El presente comité se encuentra en la ciudad de Asuncion, y se halla dentro del programa Comite de Mujeres Emprendedoras en su tercer ciclo.
La Sra. Nimia T. de 35 años de edad, tiene 2 hijos chicos que se quedan con la hermana mayor en la casa, mientras ella se va a vender el Tereré (infusión de agua fría, bebida típica del Paraguay) en La Plaza Uruguaya que se halla en el centro mismo de la ciudad, esto lo hace por la mañana, pero por la tarde tiene ventas de "Tele Bingo" (un juego de azar que se realiza por la Televisión a nivel nacional), lo realiza ya en compañía de su hijo menor.
Ella es una señora muy sufrida que tiene un dia a dia muy pesado, porque al llegar de su trabajo debe de realizar las tareas de la casa.
Tiene una casita pequeña hecha de materiales precarios, pero trabaja arduamente ya que de esta manera ella sostiene a su familia.
Ahora solicita el crédito para comprar más remedios para la preparacion del Terere y de los cartones de "Tele Bingo".
texts.en:
This group is located in the city of Asuncion and is part of the “Comite de Mujeres Emprendedoras” (Committee for Enterprising Women).  It’s in its third cycle.

Nimia T., age 35 has two children who stay at her older sister’s house while she goes out to sell Tereré (flavor infused cold water; a typical beverage in Paraguay) in the Uruguay Plaza, located in the city center.  She does this in the mornings, and in the evenings sells “Tele Bingo” (a game played on national television).  She takes her youngest son with her.

She’s been through many hardships and has a difficult  time.  After finishing her work, she must care for the household.  She has a small house build from miscellaneous materials, but she works hard because this is how she supports her family.

She is asking for this loan in order to buy supplies to prepare “Tele Bingo” cards

loans.use: to buy supplies to prepare "Tele Bingo" cards

loans.name: Grupo Brisas 3, 4, 5 & 6 Group

texts.en:
PauL. belongs to the “Grupo Brisas 3, 4, 5 & 6” (Breezes Group). The group is comprised of 20 members. Each one of them works day to day at their business activities. They do this in an area with scant resources in the city of Santo Domingo. The group is located to the north of the city. They mostly sell clothes, footwear, accessories, cosmetics, food, and other miscellaneous products.

PauL.’s family is maD. up of her five children and their parents. This young mother has been very dedicated to her work - it is one of her most favorite things to do - and to attending church. She does this to help her children be able to get ahead, become professionals, get an education, and to proviD. for their family's needs, by helping to bring extra incoming to home. Her most difficult challenge is to have their own home.

PauL.’s business is selling bacon, beef, chicken and pork. She prepares the meat in order to sell for a better price. Also, she makes local sausages with these different meats. She has been in this business for four years. She tells us that she started thanks to motivation from her aunt, who was doing the same, and she introduced PauL. to her meat supplier and recommended her for a credit client. Then, PauL. was able to apply for loans from Esperanza, and she was able to invest almost two years ago. PauL. has now had three loans with Esperanza Internacional. She is very grateful because she has been able to move forward, and she has been able to invest in her business. She will use this new loan to buy several pounds of different meats.

This group has two photos because there were too many to be in just one, and we try to have the most visible faces by having two photos

loans.use: to buy chicken, beef and pork

loans.name: Isabellah

texts.en:
This is 45-year-old Isabella.  She is single, and has three children, ages 18, 16 and 9 years old. In 1980, Isabella established her drinks and grocery business. She began her business after getting a small business loan from her friend. This business to Isabella is the only source of income to provide for her children. She opens her business six days a week and works nine hours a day. 

Isabella needs a loan of Le 3,000,000 in order to purchase drinks and groceries, such as milk, sugar, sardine, ovaltine, etc., for her business. Isabella wishes to support her children to be properly educated from the little she gets from her business. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy drinks and groceries, such as milk, sugar, sardines, ovaltine, etc., for her business

loans.name: Las Exitosas Group

texts.es:
El presente comité se encuentra en la ciudad de Asuncion, trabaja en su tercer ciclo dentro del programa.
La Sra. Dilma S. de 30 años de edad, tiene 3 hijos, todos ellos en edad escolar, por las mañanas y cuando regresan del colegio le ayudan a su mamá a desgranar el choclo y lo cargan en una bolsita de hule para vender en la zona de San Antonio (ciudad cercana a Asuncion).
Ella realiza la venta de choclo en horas de la tarde (horario en que sus hijos van a la escuela) y regresa a su casa ya cuando anochece, es muy sacrificada porque trata de sustentar a su familia, cuidar su hogar y educar a sus hijos.
Es una señora muy guapa y valiente porque lucha día a día para poder salir adelante con sus hijos ya que es madre soltera y vive en un asentamiento muy pobre de la zona.
texts.en:
This committee is located in the city of Asuncion and is in its third cycle.

Dilma S. is 30 years old and has three children, all school aged.  In the mornings, when they come home from school they help their mother husk the corn and carry it in a rubber bag to sell in the San Antonio zone (near Asuncion).

She sells corn in the evenings (when her children are in school) and returns home at night.  She makes many sacrifices because she tries to support her family, care for her household, and educate her children.

She is a very pretty and brave lady because she struggles daily to get ahead with her children.  She is a single mother who lives in a very poor part of the zone.

loans.use: to buy corn and rubber bags

loans.name: Colores Group

texts.es:
El presente comité se encuentra en su tercer ciclo, es de la ciudad de Asuncion, de un barrio muy humilde de la ciudad capitalina.
La Sra. Gladys C. tiene dos hijos, es vendedora ambulante de empanadas, sale por la mañana a hacer sus ventas en la zona de Tacumbu (zona peligrosa, cercana a la cárcel principal del Paraguay) y vuelve a su casa por la tarde.
Es una señora valiente porque recorre zonas peligrosas en su trabajo porque allí hay muchas ventas ya que nadie se anima a ir por esos lugares tan fácilmente, y todo lo hace para salir adelante con sus hijos ya que es madre soltera.
Tiene una casita pequeña pero propia, desea poder ampliarla con el tiempo y que sus hijos terminen bien el colegio, por eso solicita el crédito para poder comprar todo lo que necesita para prepara mayor cantidad de empanadas como discos de empanadas, carnes, verduras, queso, choclo, etc.
Todas las mujeres de este grupo esperan contar con el apoyo de los inversionistas de Kiva.
texts.en:
This committee is beginning its third loan cycle. Its members live in a humble neighborhood in the capital city of Asuncion city.

Gladys C. has two children. She sells empanadas from a street cart and works in Tacumbu zone (a dangerous neighborhood near the most prominent prison in Paraguay) from morning until the afternoon, when she returns to her home.

She is brave to work in such a dangerous area, but the sales are good since not many food vendors venture there. As a single mother, Gladys is willing to work there so that she can provide for her children. She owns a small house, which she hopes to expand over time. She also wishes to see her children graduate high school. Gladys is requesting a loan to buy ingredients she needs to prepare a greater quantity of empanadas, such as prepared empanada dough, meat, vegetables, cheese, maize, etc. 

All the women in this group hope to receive support from Kiva investors.

loans.use: To purchase empanada dough, meat, vegetables, cheese, maize, etc.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to renovate the bakery and buy more ingredients to add different kinds of pastry and bread to their bakery.

loans.name: Rania

texts.en: Rania J., a 27-year-old lady, started a small home business selling clothes. She started her business three years ago. She is known to carry a fine collection that would suit most of her customers' taste. She depends on word of mouth to gain more customers. Rania applied for this loan to add a new collection of clothes and accessories to the products she sells.

loans.use: to add a new collection of clothes and accessories to the products she sells.

loans.name: Alia

texts.en:
Alia is a 42-year-old mother of four children. She is known for her tasty breads and “Maftool”. She has been baking for her children since the moment they were born, and all of her neighbors and relative got to taste her bread. They encouraged her to bake at home and sell the bread.

Because of the encouragement that she got from people around her, Alia started a small business baking bread and started to make “Maftool”. She has been selling it on order for almost 10 years now.

Now Alia wants to buy a speciA. oven for baking that will help her increase her productivity. For that reason she has applied for this loan.

loans.use: To buy a special oven for home bakery.

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mariam is a 44-year-old widow; she has 3 children to raise. Since she can’t read or write, she took a few courses to learn how to make baskets from straw and how to sew the Jordanian traditionA. head covering for men “Shmagh”, so she would be able to support her family financially.

Mariam started a small business 7 years ago; she makes beautifully hand-woven baskets and handmade head covers and from selling them she has managed to support her family.

Now Mariam has applied for a loan to increase her productivity so she can increase her income each year, until she is able to open a small shop to display her work for sale.

loans.use: to buy raw materials to increase her productivity.

loans.name: Majdi

texts.en:
Majdi E. is a young man from Jabalia refugee camp. Majdi runs a fruit and vegetable shop in the refugee camp. Majdi sells seasonal fruit and vegetables and would like to enlarge his store.

Majdi took out a loan from FATEN to purchase larger amount of seasonal fruit to increase sales and attract more customers. He is photographed in front of his store.

loans.use: to purchase a larger amount of seasonal fruit.

loans.name: Sana'

texts.en:
Sana' D. is a young woman from Jabalia refugee camp. She is married and a mother of one daughter. Her husband who appears in the picture here (as she is a conservative woman) owns a construction-wood workshop where he buys wood and prepares it for construction use.

Sana' took out a loan from FATEN as her husband needs to purchase a big amount of wood to provide a construction location with wood.

loans.use: to have money to purchase wood for her husband's business.

loans.name: Ziyad

texts.en:
Ziyad is a 34-year-old father of two daughters and three sons. Ziyad's sons and daughters are growing up therefore he wants to furnish an empty room in the house for his daughters to use.

Ziyad took out a loan from FATEN to pay for the furniture as he can't afford to buy it all at once  with the salary he earns.

Ziyad is photographed in FATEN's branch in Jabalia refugee camp.

loans.use: to purchase house furniture and furnish his daughters' room.

loans.name: Wael

texts.en:
Wael is the father of one daughter and one son. He lives in Jabalia refugee camp. Wael is an employee with a very decent salary, but he has been living with very basic furniture till  his wife started work and could contribute to the household expenses.

Wael took out a loan from FATEN to purchase needed furniture such as a kitchen table, chairs and better beds for the son and daughter.

Wael is photographed above.

loans.use: to purchase home furniture.

loans.name: Huda

texts.en:
Huda is a mother of 3 children who started a small business as a hair stylist at her home two years ago. She customized one of the rooms in her house to be her work place.

During these two years she has added more than one seat to her beauty salon, and took training to be a make-up artist, too. Now Huda has applied for a loan to buy more equipment and cosmetics to help her improve the service she provides at her beauty salon.

loans.use: To buy more equipment and cosmetics.

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali is a young man from Gaza city in Gaza Strip. Ali finished his school few months ago and started working recently. Ali's brothers helped him when he was a student and paid his tuition fees and school expenses.

Now that Ali is working, he wants to pay back his brothers, so he took out a loan from FATEN in order to have only one payment to make.

Ali appears in the picture here.

loans.use: to repay brothers who paid Ali's school tuition fees.

loans.name: Ghena

texts.en:
Ghena Khalid is the mother of two children. She turned one of her rooms at her house into a small shop to sell snacks a year ago to help support the family. All the kids in the neighborhood are now used to going to her house to buy their snacks.

 Ghena has been running her humble business for one year now and is looking to add more variety in the products she sells, such as adding grocery products. In order to do that, Ghena has applied for this loan so it can help her business grow and maybe have a separate grocery shop outside her house in the future.

loans.use: To add more variety to the food items she sells.

loans.name: Meas

texts.en: Meas P., 27, is married and lives with her two young children in the Takeo province. She raises pigs and works as a farmer, making approximately $1.50 each day, and her husband works in construction. Her family is also supported by her husband’s $5 daily income. Meas P. is asking for a loan of $1,200 to purchase a motorbike. This motorbike will help her to reduce her daily transportation costs.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike in order to reduce her daily transportation costs

loans.name: Eam

texts.en: Eam M. is 43 years old and sells fruits in Takeo Province. Her business has been around for about four years, and she makes US$10 every day. Her husband has been working as a local Khmer teacher since 1990 and is able to make US$3 per day. Eam M. is now requesting a loan of US$1000 in order to increase her stock of fruits to sell.

loans.use: to buy more fruits to expand the business.

loans.name: Hiem

texts.en: Hiem V., 41, is married and lives with her six children in Takeo Province. She is a farmer who works for less than US$1 each day, while her husband is employed as a commune consultant and earns US$5 each day. The family is supported by three children working in a garment factory. Hiem V. is now requesting a loan of US$650 to purchase cows to help plow the rice fields.

loans.use: to buy cows to help plow the rice field.

loans.name: Chea

texts.en: Chea H., 64, is a widow and a traditional cake seller in Takeo province. She is able to earn US $4 each day. Chea H. now lives with one of her daughters who works as a grocery seller, making US $8 per day. To earn more money, Chea H. is asking for a loan of US $1,000 to purchase rice in bulk for resale. She is confident that this loan will allow her to increase her daily income and to better support her family.

loans.use: to buy rice in bulk for resale.

loans.name: Bun

texts.en: Bun E., 58, is a local teacher who lives with her husband and four of her children in Takeo province. She is able to earn US $2.50 per day, while her husband, a village chief, earns US $1 per day. This family is supported by their four children who work in garment factories. Bun E. now wants to take out a loan of US $1,200 to breed cows.

loans.use: to buy cows to breed.

loans.name: Meas

texts.en:
Meas R., 50, is married and lives with her eight children in Takeo province. She is a farmer who works for less than US $1 each day, while her husband works in construction making US $5 each day. This family is also supported by three of the children who are garment factory workers.

Weather conditions have been difficult for farming in Cambodia this past year and inflation has caused food prices to skyrocket. These factors have played into a difficult economic year for many Cambodians, Meas R. included. In light of these economic difficulties, she is asking for a loan of US $1,000 to purchase fertilizer and a motorbike for her children to commute to school.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and a motorbike for her children to commute to school.

loans.name: Mak

texts.en: Mak S., 41, sells fish at the local market in Takeo province. She has been selling fish since 2006, and is able to make about US $4 of profit each day. She has three school-aged children living at home to support. Her husband is a professional television repairman, who usually makes US $5 per day. Mak S. wants to take out a loan of US $500 to purchase more tools for her husband. S. is unavailable, so her husband appears in the photograph instead.

loans.use: to buy more tools for her husband.

loans.name: Lei

texts.en: Lei S., 51, lives with her husband and five of her children in Takeo. She is a farmer and also raises chickens from home. On average, she is able to make about US$3 of profit each day. Two of her children are in school, while three are employed as garment factory workers. Her husband is a traditional medicine seller, making US$5 per day. Lei S. would like to take out a loan of US$500 to purchase a motorbike for her husband to transport medicine and sell around the village.

loans.use: buy a motorbike for her husband's business

loans.name: Divino Niño Jesus Group

texts.es:
Divino Niño Jesus se denomina el excelente grupo de mujeres conformado en la ciudad de Ita en fecha 28 de agosto de 2008, gracias a que la actual Directora General, la Sra. Dina B., contactó con la asesora en una reunión semanal que la misma tenía en la zona para enterarse de la forma de trabajo que tiene el Comité de Mujeres.
Son 18 mujeres, quienes se encuentran trabajando muy a gusto ya en el 7° ciclo, en forma conjunta y solidaria dentro del programa.
La sra. Dina tiene venta de comidas en su casa, está casada y tiene 2 hijos varones, ella es una mujer que lucha cada día para adquirir una buena cantidad de ingresos económicos para su familia, pues sabe que la vida es dura y como desea que sus hijos posean todo lo que necesitan le ayuda de esta manera a su marido a sustentar la canasta familiar.
Ella solicita el crédito para poder comprar verduras, harinas, azúcar, frutas, entre otras cosas, de modo a poder preparar más comidas y vender a más personas.
texts.en:
Divino Niño Jesus is the name of the excellent group of women formed in the city of Ita on August 28, 2008 thanks to the current Director General, Dina B., who contacted the consultant in a weekly meeting that she had in the area to learn how to work like the Women's Committee.

They are 18 women who are working comfortably in the seventh cycle together in the program. Dina sells food from her home. She is married and has two sons. She is a woman who fights every day to acquire a good quantity of economic income for her family since she knows that life is hard and she wishes that her children possess all that they need. In this way, she helps her husband to support the family.

She is requesting the loan to be able to buy vegetables, flour, sugar, fruit, among other things in order to be able to prepare more food and sell to more people.

loans.use: to purchase vegetables, flour, sugar, fruit, etc.

loans.name: Las Margaritas Group

texts.es:
Las Margaritas se denomina el excelente grupo de mujeres conformado en la ciudad de Itá, gracias a que la Sra. Rossana G. contactó con la asesora para informarse de la forma de trabajo que tiene el Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras, una vez asesorada acerca del Programa logró juntar a 16 mujeres quienes se encuentran trabajando muy a gusto ya en el 7° ciclo.
La sra. Rossana se dedica a la venta de cosméticos, ella compra de una fábrica a precios de costo base y los vende con un margen de ganancia, pero últimamente no ha tenido la suficiente cantidad de productos para vender ya que sus clientes han aumentado en cantidad, por eso desea el crédito de Kiva para poder comprar más productos de diversas marcas y calidades y ofrecer a sus distintas clases de clientes.
Todas las mujeres de este comité desean poder aumentar su calidad de vida y bienestar general.
texts.en:
Las Margaritas is the name of an excellent group of women from the city of Itá. Originally, Rossana G. contacted a credit officer to learn more about the services of Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras. Once approved, 16 women joined the group and they have been working together very well. The group is already in its 7th loan cycle.

Rossana sells cosmetics, buying at wholesale prices and selling with a profit margin. However, Rossana hasn't had enough working capital to keep up with the growth of her customer base. This is why she is requesting a loan from Kiva in order to buy more products. She wants to buy products from different brands and price ranges to be able to offer to different customer types.

All the women in this group hope to be able to improve their quality of life and general wellbeing.

loans.use: To purchase cosmetics.

loans.name: El Eden 3 Group

texts.en:
Diosa is the coordinator of her group El Eden (Eden) 3, and her group is located in the rural areas surrounding Hato Mayor, an area where the economy is centered around agriculture and where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure with her husband and their two children.

Diosa is excited to be taking her second loan with Kiva partner Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loan and grown her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her Beauty Salon by purchasing a large quantity of beauty products and to repair some of the structure. She will use the profits to re-invest in her business. She said that her most difficult challenge is to help her children to become professionals, by attending school up to university.

She started doing her business after she worked in a beauty salon and then decided to have her own business. For her future she is dreaming of building apartment and renting them.  She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: to buy beauty products and rebuild he rlocal  business

loans.name: Merly Jacquelina

texts.es:
En la ciudadela El Progreso de la ciudad de Portoviejo se reúne cada quince días el Banco Comunal Girasoles, esta es una zona urbano marginal muy poblada en esta ciudad. Se la conoce como el sector de la cárcel ya que en esta zona queda la cárcel de mujeres de Portoviejo.

En este lugar conocimos a la señora Merly, tiene 30 años de edad, mantiene una relación de unión libre de la cual ha procreado dos hijos de 8 y 3 años de edad, el mayor estudia en escuela. Su marido se dedica a la  albañilería.

Ella es una ama de casa que se dedica a  la venta de ropa y a la  elaboración y venta de bolos (helados de hielo en funda), tiene su negocio en su casa donde  produce y vende bolos de distintos sabores, trabaja tres días a la semana en las ventas ropa y esto lo hace por las mañanas y en las tardes y el resto de la semana se  dedica a preparar sus deliciosos  bolos de distintos sabores que son muy solicitados por sus clientes.
 
Este crédito es para comprar pantalones, camisas, blusas, entre otras prendas. Es socia del Banco Comunal hace 7 ciclos y le gusta por los beneficios que le da la institución.
 
Su sueño es tener su casa bien construida.
texts.en:
The communal bank Girasoles (Sunflowers) meets every fifteen days in the El Progreso district of the city of Portoviejo. This is a heavily populated district on the edge of the city. It is known as the jail district, since the women's jail of Portoviejo is in this sector. 

Here we meet Señora Merly. She is 30 years old. She lives in a common-law marriage that has produced two children, ages 8 and 3. The older child is in school. Her husband works as a mason.

She is a housewife who sells clothing and also prepares and sells "bolos" (frozen treats sold in a wrapper). She runs her business from her home, where she produces and sells bolos of different flavors. She works three days a week selling clothing in the morning and in the afternoon, and the rest of the week she works preparing her delicious bolos of different flavors, which are greatly requested by her customers.

This loan is to buy pants, shirts, and blouses, among other clothing items. She has been a member of her communal bank for seven loan cycles, and she likes it because of the benefits that the institution provides.

Her dream is to have a well-constructed house.

loans.use: to buy pants, shirts, and other clothing items to sell.

loans.name: Irma Monserrate

texts.es:
En la ciudadela El Progreso de la ciudad de Portoviejo se reúne cada quince días el Banco Comunal Ilusiones, esta es una zona urbano marginal muy poblada en esta ciudad. Se la conoce como el sector de la cárcel ya que en esta zona queda la cárcel de mujeres de Portoviejo.

En este lugar conocimos a la señora Irma, tiene 44 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tienen tres hijos de 23, 22 y 17 años de edad, todos sus hijos  aun viven con ella y estudian los mayores en universidad y el menor en colegio. Su esposo es comerciante.

Ella se dedica a la venta de medicinas naturales, su forma de venta es puerta a puerta y  también vende en su casa hasta donde llegan sus clientes  a comprar estos productos. Trabaja todos los días desde las 8h30 hasta las 17h00, sus productos deja a crédito y cobra semanalmente dice que le encanta vender. Lleva un año en este tipo de ventas y nos cuenta que tiene muchos clientes ya que el producto que ella ofrece es muy bueno. Sus productos los  compra en Guayaquil.

Este crédito lo va emplear en comprar más medicinas naturales de todo tipo. Está en el Banco Comunal desde hace dos ciclos  y le gusta la ayuda que recibe del banco. 

Su sueño es tener un local para vender sus productos.
texts.en:
In the neighborhood of El Progreso, in the city of Portoviejo, the "Ilusiones" ["Dreams"] communal bank meets every fifteen days. This neighborhood is a densely populated marginal urban zone of the city. It is known as the prison sector, since the women's prison of Portoviejo is located here.

In this place, we meet Irma, who is 44 years old and married. She and her husband have three children, aged 23, 22 and 17. All of her children still live with her; the older ones are studying at the university and the youngest is in school. Her husband is a merchant.

Irma works selling natural medicines. She sells them door to door, and she also sells in her home, where her customers come to buy these products. She works every day from 8:30 a.m. to 5 p.m. She sells her products on credit and collects each week. She reports that she loves selling. She has done this type of selling for one year, and she reports that she has many clients, since the products she offers are very good. She buys her products in Guayaquil.

She will use this loan to buy more natural medicines of all types. She has been in her communal bank for two loan cycles, and she likes the help she receives from the bank. 

Her dream is to have a store where she can sell her products.

loans.use: to buy natural medicines to sell.

loans.name: Mayita Dolores

texts.es:
En la ciudadela El Progreso de la ciudad de Portoviejo se reúne cada quince días el Banco Comunal Girasoles, esta es una zona urbano marginal muy poblada en esta ciudad. Se la conoce como el sector de la cárcel ya que en esta zona queda la cárcel de mujeres de Portoviejo.

Aquí encontramos a la señora Mayita, tiene 34 años y mantiene una relación de unión libre de la cual ha procreado tres hijos de 12, 9  y 1 año, el mayor esta en colegio el segundo en escuela. Su marido se dedica a la albañilería.

Es una ama de casa que además de cuidar su hogar y a sus hijos también se dedica al comercio, vende sabanas y edredones, trabaja tres o cuatro días a la semana por las mañanas y por las noches desde las 18h00 hasta las 20h00, no trabaja en las tardes porque a esa hora tiene que ayudarles a sus hijos a realizar sus tareas escolares, y en las noches su marido se queda con ellos mientras ella realiza sus ventas. Tiene cuatro años que se dedica a esta actividad.

Este crédito es para comprar sabanas, edredones y un poco de ropa que le han pedido algunos clientes. Este es su séptimo  ciclo en el Banco Comunal y le gusta porque se divierte en las reuniones.
 
Su sueño es tener algún día un almacén.
texts.en:
In the El Progreso neighborhood of the city of Portoviej the community bank Girasoles meets every two weeks. This is a highly populated area on the outskirts of town. It is known as the jail district, since the women's jail of Portoviejo is in that area.  

Here we find Mayita. She is 34 years old and in a common law marriage which has resulted in three children, aged 12, 9 and 1. The oldest is in high school and the second child is on elementary schol. Her husband is a bricklayer.  

She is a housewife, who in addition to managing her household and her children, is a merchant. She sells sheets and comforters. She works three or four days a week in the morning and at night from 6 p.m. until 8 p.m. She doesn't work afternoons, because that is when she has to help her children do their homework. At night, her husband stays with them while she does her sales. She has been doing this activity for four years.  

This loan is to buy sheets, comforters and a little bit of clothing that some customers have asked her for. This is her seventh cycle with the community bank and she likes it because she has fun at the meetings. 
 
Her dream is to have a store some day.

loans.use: to buy sheets, comforters and clothing.

loans.name: María Eugenia

texts.es:
En la ciudadela El Progreso de la ciudad de Portoviejo se reúne cada quince días el Banco Comunal Ilusiones, esta es una zona urbano marginal muy poblada en esta ciudad. Se la conoce como el sector de la cárcel ya que en esta zona queda la cárcel de mujeres de Portoviejo.

Aquí conocimos a la señora María, Tiene 42 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tiene  5 hijos, tres de ellos ya son mayores de edad y los otros dos tienen 17 y 12 años los mismos que estudian en colegio. El esposo es conserje.
 
Ella es una muy buena ama de casa que además se dedica a la preparación y venta de corviches, empanadas y helados de varios sabores, tiene un pequeño local en su casa donde todas las tardes vende empanadas y corviches porque los helados los vende todo el día, por las  mañanas se dedica a elaborar  sus productos y en las tardes a las venta de los mismos. Nos cuenta que lleva 5 años que se dedica a esta actividad y que le ha ido muy bien. 

Este crédito lo va a emplear para comprar maní, plátano verde, pescado, aceite, frutas, entre otros materiales necesarios para la preparación de los alimentos. Este es su quinto ciclo en el Banco Comunal y le encantan por que ha recibido mucha ayuda del banco y de la institución. 
 
Su sueño es tener un restaurante.
texts.en:
In the El Progreso neighborhood of the city of Portoviejo, the community bank Ilusiones meets every two weeks. This is a highly populated area on the outskirts of the city. It is known as the jail district because Portoviejo's women's jail is in the area.  

Here we meet María. She is 42 years old, married and the mother of 5 children. Three of them are grown and the others are 17 and 12. They go to high school. Her husband is a janitor.   
 
She is a good housewife who also makes and sells corviches, empanadas and differently flavored ice creams. She has a small locale in her house where she sells empanadas and corviches every afternoon. She sells the ice cream all day long. In the morning, she makes her products and sells them in the afterrnoon. She tells us that she has been doing this activity for 5 years, and it has gone very well for her.  

She is going to use this loan to buy more peanuts, green plantains, fish, oil, fruit and other ingredients she needs to prepare the foods. This is her fifth cycle in the community bank and she loves them, because she has she has received a lot of help from the bank and the institution. 
 
Her dream is to have a restaurant.

loans.use: to buy peanuts, green plantains, fish, oil, fruit, etc.

loans.name: San Blas Group

texts.es:
El Comité de Mujeres de nombre San Blás, se conformó en fecha 23 de abril del 2009, gracias a que la Sra. Tomasa O., quien ya había participado del programa en otro grupo anteriormente, decidió conformar su propio grupo y contactó con la asesora para su conformación.
Actualmente está conformado por 16 mujeres que se encuentran trabajando ya en el 4to. Ciclo, en forma conjunta y solidaria dentro del programa. Es un excelente grupo gracias al  trabajo solidario realizado y continuan trabajando hasta estos días.
La sra. Tomasa se dedica a la confección de prendas de vestir para damas y caballeros, ella posee este oficio desde hace mucho tiempo, desde que era una adolescente, se percató de que es una buena manera de generar ingresos si se realizan los trabajos con buena calidad.
Gracias a su buen trato y al buen prestigio de sus prendas ha ido aumentando la cantidad de clientes y hoy día solicita el crédito para poder comprar más materiales de modo que pueda abastecer los pedidos de las personas y que queden satisfechas.
texts.en:
The Committee of Women of the name San Blás was formed on April 23 2009, thanks to Tomasa O. who had already participated in the program in another group. She decided to form her own group and contacted the consultant to do so. Currently, it is made up of 16 women that are working in their fourth cycle in a unified manner in the program. It is an excellent group thanks to the work performed and they continue working to this day.

Tomasa is dedicated to making women's and men's clothing. She has performed this job for a long time, since she was an adolescent. She realized that it is a good way to generate income if you can complete the work with good quality. Thanks to her good treatment and the prestige of her work, the number of customers has increased and today she is requesting a loan to be able to buy more materials so that she can fill the orders from people so they stay satisfied.

loans.use: to purchase fabric, thread, embroidery frames and other sewing items.

loans.name: Dolores Ernestina

texts.es:
En la ciudadela El Progreso de la ciudad de Portoviejo se reúne cada quince días el Banco Comunal Ilusiones esta es una zona urbano marginal muy poblada en esta ciudad. Se la conoce como el sector de la cárcel ya que en esta zona queda la cárcel de mujeres de Portoviejo.

En este lugar conocimos a la señora Dolores, tiene 26 años de edad y mantiene una relación de unión libre de la cual tiene dos hijos de 12 y 10 años los mismos que estudia en colegio y  escuela. Su marido es albañil.

Ella vende productos para el hogar (planchas, licuadoras, ventiladores, camas, etc.), ropa y zapatos de todo tipo. Su forma de venta es por cartilla o por catalogo, enseña la revista donde están todos estos artículos y sus clientes deciden que es lo que quieren y luego ella al completar el cupo limite realiza los pedidos y entrega los productos de acuerdo al número que tengan sus clientes, cobra cada semanas o cada quince como prefieran sus clientes. Nos cuenta que lleva 4 años realizando esta labor y que le va bien.

Este crédito es para comprar planchas, licuadoras, ventiladores, camas, ropa y zapatos.  Este es su cuarto ciclo en el Banco Comunal y le gusta porque con los créditos ha podido sacar adelante su negocio.

Su sueño es tener su propia distribuidora de estos productos.
texts.en:
The Ilusiones ("Hopes") communal bank meets fortnightly at the El Progreso residential community, a deprived, densely populated area in the city of Portoviejo. It's known as the prison neighbourhood, as it's where Portoviejo's women's prison is located. Here we meet Dolores, 26, who lives with her partner and their two children, aged 12 and 10. The children go to school and her partner is a bricklayer.  

She sells all kinds of household products (irons, blenders, fans, beds, etc..), clothing and shoes. She sells via catalogue. She shows her customers the brochures of the different articles and they decide on what they want. Upon reaching the minimum quota of orders she places the orders and delivers the products to her clients as requested. She gets paid weekly or fortnightly, depending on what her clients prefer. She explains that she has been in this line of business for 4 years and that things are going well for her. 

This loan is to buy irons, blenders, fans, beds, clothes and shoes. This is her fourth cycle with the communal bank and she enjoys it because thanks to the loans she has been able to succeed in her business. 

Her dream is to have her own distribution company for this kind of products.

loans.use: to buy irons, blenders, fans, beds, clothes and shoes.

loans.name: Esther 1, 3 & 4 Group

texts.en:
Margarita is the group coordinator of Esther 1, 3 & 4 which is maD. up of fifteen micro-entrepreneurs. Margarita lives with her long term partner and three children. She said that her most difficult challenge is to improve her business and proviD. change in her family.

Margarita operates a miscellaneous sales business by selling cosmetics, shoes, clothes, and other items. She will use the loan to purchase many items to increase her business inventory. She is excited to received her 9th loan with Esperanza and her group, as with each loan she has been able to start her business and improve it, making it possible to proviD. for her family needs and introduce different products to her children.

Margarita represents women who decided to start small businesses to supplement the insufficient incomes their households receive. This group is located in the city of San Pedro D. Macoris, in one of the rural  village surrounding the main city. Margarita enjoys to work and be at her home with her family.

She thanks all of you for your support to her business and her group.

This group has two photos because there were too many to be in just one, and we tried to have the most visible faces by having two photos.

loans.use: to buy clothing, shoes, cosmetics, accessories, etc.

loans.name: Nueva Esperanza Group

texts.es:
El contacto para el inicio del presente comité fue la señora Gladis M., quien invitó y organizó a sus amigas para formar parte del programa Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras.
La sra. Gladis M. se dedica a la venta de comestible, ella está en pareja desde hace 15 años con el señor Francisco Galeano quien se dedica a la albañilería, tienen cuatro hijos estudiantes, dos en la secundaria y uno en la primaria.
La señora Gladis M. solicita el crédito para la compra de ingredientes y elementos para su trabajo (huevos, harina, carne, leche, aceite y cacerolas).
Ella sueña con abrir un copetin y de esa manera brindar lo mejor a sus hijos en el aspecto de la vivienda, educación, ocio, etc.
Todas las mujeres del grupo son personas muy dedicadas a sus familias y desean poder contar con la ayuda de los inversionistas de Kiva.
texts.en:
Gladis M. is the woman who started this group. She invited and organized a group of her friends so that they could participate in the Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras program.

Gladis M. sells groceries. She has been married for 15 years to Francisco Galeano, who is a bricklayer. The couple have four children who are all in school: two are in high school and one is in elementary school. She is requesting a loan to buy ingredients and products for her business (eggs, flour, meat, milk, oil and saucepans).

She dreams of opening a snack stand and using income to provide a better home, schooling, and life for her children. All the women in this group are very dedicated to their families and hope to have the support of Kiva investors.

loans.use: To buy eggs, milk, meat, oil and saucepans.

loans.name: Nueva Union 3 & 4 Group

texts.en:
Bernarda is one of the members of a group called Nueva Union 3 & 4 (New Union), and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) clients generally. Her group is located in Samana, a lush but rugged peninsula with a nascent tourism industry, where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She enjoys attending church and sharing with her group friends. She is very committed to improving her business and helping others joined in solidarity.

Bernarda is excited to be taking her first loan with Esperanza and is excited for the opportunity to grow her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business selling clothes by walking to and taking the clothing into different communities. She sells different models and styles. She will use the profits to invest in her home by purchasing food and repairing her house, she need to make some changes to it. She would also like to save to reinvest if someone orders a bigger quantity. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: to buy clothes to sell.

loans.name: Mujeres Con Visión (Cuenca) Group

texts.es:
El banco comunal Mujeres con Visión está conformado por 11 mujeres trabajadoras, luchadoras y siempre en busca de un mejor futuro para sus familias, laboran en diferentes actividades las mismas que les permiten mejorar su situación económica. Viven en diferentes partes de la ciudad de Cuenca, esta ciudad es clima frió y tiene un hermoso centro histórico colonial es mismo que es admirado por propios y extraños, su gente mantiene su cultura y tradiciones.

La Señora. Zulay Elizabeth N. vive por el centro de la ciudad de Cuenca, se encuentra en el segundo crédito que realiza en el banco comunal y le gustan los créditos ya que le permiten crecer en su negocio.
 
Nuestra socia es comerciante, ella se dedica a la venta de ropa, esta actividad  la realiza hace 2 años y solo trabaja los días de feria. Ahora va a iniciar  un nuevo negocio que es la venta de comida rápida.

Doña Zulay tiene 28 años, vive en unión libre y tiene 3 hijos de 9, 8 y 6 años de edad que estudian en una escuelita de la ciudad. Su esposo es de profesión electricista, no tienen casa propia por lo que viven arrendando. 

El dinero de su crédito lo va a invertir en la compra de productos para la preparación de la comida rápida como: carne, salchichas, pan, arroz, papas, etc.

Su meta es sacar adelante a sus hijos.
texts.en:
The Mujeres con Visión (Women with Vision) community bank is made up of 11 hard-working, determined women who are always in search of a better future for their families.  They are all engaged in different business activities which allow them to improve their financial situation.  They live in different parts of the city of Cuenca.  This is a cold-climate city with a beautiful historic, colonial center which is admired by both locals and strangers alike.  Its people maintain their culture and traditions.

Zulay Elizabeth N. lives in Cuenca city center.  This is the second loan that she has accessed through her community bank and she likes the loans since they allow her to grow in her business.  Zulay sells clothes.  She has been in this business for two years and she only works on market days.  She is about to start a new business selling fast food.

Zulay is 28 years old.  She lives with her partner and has three children aged 9, 8 and 6 who are attending an elementary school in the city.  Her husband is an electrician by profession.  They don't own their own home but live in a rental house.

Zulay will invest her loan money in buying products with which to prepare her fast food such as meat, sausages, bread, rice, potatoes, etc.  Her goal is to get her children ahead in life.

loans.use: to buy meat, sausages, bread, rice, potatoes, etc.

loans.name: Martha Victoria

texts.es:
La Señora. Martha M. es socia del banco comunal Mujeres de la Bahía, vive en la ciudad de Azogues, esta ciudad es reconocida por su belleza colonial, cuenta con hermosas iglesias, su gente se dedica al comercio, mantienen su cultura y tradiciones.
 
Doña Martha tiene 47 años, es casada y tiene 4 hijos de 21, 18, 16 y 10 años de edad, sus tres primeros hijos estudian en el colegio y su ultimo hijo en una escuela de la ciudad. Su esposo es de profesión policía, la casa en la que habitan es propia.
 
La Señora. Martha se dedica a la venta de frutas y verduras en un mercado de la ciudad, esta actividad  la realiza hace 32 años ya que empezó desde que tenía apenas 15 años, labora de domingo a domingo desde las 9 de la mañana hasta las 6 de la tarde.
 
Se encuentra en el octavo crédito que realiza en el banco comunal y  lo va a invertir en la compra de frutas y hortalizas.
 
Su meta es crecer más en el negocio.
texts.en:
Martha M., age 47, is married and has four children aged 21, 18, 16, and 10.  Her husband is a policeman; they have a house of their own. Martha is a member of the communal bank Mujeres de la Bahía; she lives in the city of Azogues which is known for its colonial-era charm and its beautiful churches. Its people maintain their culture and traditions. 
 
Martha makes her living selling fruit and vegetables in the city market. She has been employed in this line of work for 32 years; she started it when she had just turned 15. Her work schedule is from Sunday to Sunday, from 9am to 6pm. Martha is now in her eighth loan cycle and plans to use the funds to purchase fruit and vegetables. Her goal is to grow her business.

loans.use: to purchase fruit and vegetables

loans.name: María Cristina

texts.es:
La Señora María es socia del banco comunal Mujeres de la Bahía, vive por el Sector de San Marco en la ciudad de Azogues, esta ciudad es conocida por su belleza colonial, cuenta con hermosas iglesias, su gente se dedica al comercio, mantienen su cultura y tradiciones.
 
Doña María tiene 59 años, está separada y tiene 8 hijos de los cuales 6  son casados y sus 2 hijos solteros trabajan y le ayudan económicamente. Con su trabajo y esfuerzo ha construido su casa propia.

La Señora. María se dedica a la agricultura y a la venta de frutas y hortalizas en un mercado de la ciudad, esta actividad la realiza desde que tenia 14 años de edad, trabaja todos los días desde las 8 de la mañana hasta las 5 de la tarde.

Este es el primer crédito que realiza en el banco comunal al cual invitada por una amiga que es socia, Su crédito lo va a invertir en la compra de frutas y hortalizas para surtir más su negocio.
 
Su sueño es no tener deudas.
texts.en:
María is a member of the Mujeres de la Bahía community bank.  She lives in San Marco neighborhood, in the city of Azogues.  This city is known for its colonial beauty.  It has beautiful churches and its people work in commerce.  They maintain their culture and traditions.

María is 59 years old, separated, and has eight children.  Six of her children are married and her two children who are single work and help her out financially.  Through her work and effort, she has built her own home.

María is a farmer and also sells fruit and vegetables in a market in the city.  She has been in this business since she was 14 years old.  She works every day, from 8.00am to 5.00pm.

This is the first loan that María has accessed through her community bank which she was invited to join by a friend who is a member.  She will invest her loan in buying fruit and vegetables to further stock her business.

María's dream is to not have any debts.

loans.use: to buy fruit and vegetables

loans.name: Las Escogidas 7, 8 & 9 Group

texts.en:
Anelis is the coordinator of her group Las Escogidas (The Chosen) 7, 8 & 9 . She makes her home here in a simple structure with her long-term partner and their two children. This group is located in one of rural villages surrounding the main city of San Pedro D. Macoris.

Having repaid her previous loan and grown her business, Anelis is excited to be taking her third loan with Esperanza. She has operated her business for around 3 years, selling miscellaneous products such as clothes, shoes, jewelry, cosmetics and many other items. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business by buying a bit of each item to increase her inventory and to get more clients. 

Anelis said that her most difficult challenge is to dedicate all her effort and profits to improve her business. She wants to have a big store where she can proviD. products that her community needs since her neighbors must now leave the community to get these items.

This Esperanza associate began with us because she needed capital to invest in her business. Her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) clients generally

loans.use: to buy clothing, shoes, cosmetics and other items.

loans.name: Patricia Raquel

texts.es:
La Señora. Patricia P. es socia del banco comunal Mujeres de la Bahía, vive por el Sector de Charasol en la ciudad de Azogues, esta ciudad es conocida por belleza colonial, cuenta con hermosas iglesias, su gente se dedica al comercio, mantienen su cultura y tradiciones.
