La Señora. Patricia tiene 35 años, es casada y tiene 2 hijos de 9 y 7 años que estudian en una escuelita de la ciudad. Su esposo es de profesión policía, con el trabajo conyugal han logrado construir su casa propia.
 
Doña Patricia tiene una tienda de comestibles y lleva 13 años en este negocio, trabaja de domingo a domingo desde las 7 de la mañana hasta las 10 de la noche.

Se encuentra en el segundo crédito que realiza en el banco comunal al cual fue invitada por una amiga. El dinero de su crédito lo va a invertir en la compra de productos para su tienda como: arroz, azúcar, fideos, detergentes, aceites, embutidos y más productos de primera necesidad.

Su sueño es no tener deudas.
texts.en:
Patricia P. is a member of the Mujeres de la Bahía community bank.  She lives in Charasol neighborhood, in the city of Azogues.  This city is known for its colonial beauty.  It has beautiful churches and its people work in commerce.  They maintain their culture and traditions.
 
Patricia is 35 years old, married, and has two children aged 9 and 7 who attend an elementary school in the city.  Her husband is a policeman by profession.  Through their joint work, they have managed to build their own hom.

Patricia owns a grocery store and has been in this business for 13 years.  She works from Sunday to Sunday, from 7.00am to 10.00pm.

This is Patricia's second loan through her community bank which she was invited to join by a friend.  She will invest her loan in buying products for her store such as rice, sugar, noodles, detergents, oils, cold cuts and other essential household products.

Patricia's dream is to not have any debts.

loans.use: to buy rice, sugar, noodles, detergents, oils, cold cuts and other essential household products

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy used tires for his business

loans.name: Kadiatu

texts.en: This is 54-year-old Kadiatu.  She is married to a retired brewery factory labourer. She has 2 dependents:  her granddaughter and one of her relatives.  In 2007, Kadiatu established her business selling local foodstuffs.  Working 7 days a week and 9 hours a day, she earns about Le 600,000 every month from this business. She would like a loan in the amount of Le 3,000,000 to purchase more local food for her business. She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately Le 150,000.  She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy more local foodstuff for her business

loans.name: Yeanoh

texts.en:
This is 41-year-old Yeanoh S.. She is divorced and has 4 children, aged 21, 18, 15 and 11 years. She has 3 additional dependents who live with her  -- they are her elder brother’s children.  In 2008, Yeanoh established a business selling cooked rice. She began her business because it is the only means of taking care of her family. Working 6 days a week and 7 hours a day, she earns about Le 400,000 every month from this business.

Yeanoh S. would like a loan in the amount of Le 3,000,000 to buy rice, palm oil, pepper and other materials that she uses for cooking. She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately Le 150,000. In the future, Yeanoh plans to build a house and educate her children to university level. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: buy rice and other cooking materials for her business

loans.name: Mohamed

texts.en:
This is 30-year-old Mohamed S..  He is married and has 1 child who is 10 years old. In the year 2002, Mohamed established his mobile phone top-up cards business.  He began his business because he wants to increase his income and be self-employed.  Working 7 days a week and 20 hours a day, he earns about Le 700,000 every month from this business. 

Mohamed would like a loan in the amount of Le 3,000,000  to buy more top-up cards for his business. He hopes that this loan will enable him to increase his monthly profits by approximately Le 200,000.  He thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy Top-up cards for mobile phones

loans.name: Arlene

texts.en:
Arlene is 42 years old and a widow with three children. Her oldest child is only 14 years old.

Arlene is engaged in farming. She grows corn and sells her harvest to the market. Arlene works hard to provide for her children. She wants them to be able to go to college and have bright futures.

This loan will be used to purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs

loans.name: Sek

texts.en: Sek C., 40, is married and resides in Kampong Cham province, an area known for Angkorean Temples. C. is a housewife.  Her husband is a gardener who earns an income of about USD 2.5 per day. Each month, the family must spend USD 60 on food and USD 30 on the other necessary expenses. C. is requesting a loan of USD 800 to purchase a motorbike for her children to commute to work. This will be her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: buy a motorbike for the children to commute to work

loans.name: Man

texts.en: Man S. is from Reussey Keo commune of Phnom Penh city. She is a 59 year-old woman who earns a living as a tailor, providing her service to neighbors by sewing both traditional clothes and modern clothes. Her business is running very well and a lot of customers recognize the good service she provides. She can earn an average of $3 US per day from her business. She is a married woman and the mother of six single children. Three of her daughters are garment factory workers. Her husband works as a motor taxi driver to support her financially. Man S. will be using her loan to purchase additional cloth for her tailoring service and will use the rest to buy seeds for planting.

loans.use: to purchase additional cloth for her tailoring service and to buy seeds for planting.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a drum of engine oil,top-up cards, break oil and Oil filters for his business.

loans.name: Belen

texts.en:
58-year-old Belen lives in the town of Banga, South Cotabato with her family. She is married and has four children. 

Belen is engaged in farming and primarily grows corn. She sells her harvest to the market. She also makes rice cakes and other delicacies. Belen is planning to raise pigs in her backyard. She says that the extra income will help her family a lot.

Belen's loan will be used to purchase fertilizers and ingredients for making rice cakes. She hopes to earn enough to start raising pigs.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and ingredients for making rice cakes

loans.name: Suy

texts.en: Suy P., 39, is married and resides in Siem Reap province, Cambodia. P. sells groceries, earning an income of about USD 5 per day. Each month, the family must spend USD 80 on food and USD 30 on the other necessary expenses. P. is requesting a loan of USD 1200 to purchase chickens and fish to raise for sale. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: buy chickens and fish to raise and sell

loans.name: Mabel

texts.en:
This is 34-year-old Mabel K..  She is single and has 3 children, aged 5, 13 and 15. In 2003, Mabel established her drinks and provisions business. When she dropped out of school, she started this business to help her provide a livelihood for her children. Working 7 days a week and 12 hours a day, she earns about Le 600,000 every month from this business. 

Mabel would like a loan in the amount of Le 3,000,000 to buy more drinks and provisions such as tea, milk, ovaltine, sugar, sardine, etc. for her business. She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately Le 100,000. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: buy drinks and provisions to sell

loans.name: Veth

texts.en: Veth S., 41, is married and resides in Siem Reap province, Cambodia, in an area known for Angkorean Temples. S. is a massager and a grocery seller, earning an income of about USD 6 per day. Each month, her family must spend USD 75 on food and USD 37 on the other necessary expenses. S. is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to purchase a motorbike to commute to work. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: buy a motorbike to commute to work

loans.name: Loa

texts.en: Loa L., age 41, is married and resides in Siem Reap province, Cambodia, an area known for Angkorean Temples.  L. is a housewife while her husband is a motorbike repairman, earning an income of about 6 USD per day.  Each month, the family has to spend 60 USD on food and 37 USD on other necessary expenses. L. is requesting a loan of 500 USD to purchase a tuk-tuk for her husband to provide transportation services for tourists. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy tuk tuk to provide transportation services for tourists.

loans.name: Santa Librada Group

texts.es:
El comité “Santa Librada” se formó con la unión de varias vecinas de la ciudad de Mariano Roque Alonso.
Todas las integrantes del comité desarrollan actividades diferentes, pero a veces realizan actividades en conjunto para recaudar fondos para su comité en caso de necesidad.
Las integrantes son personas humildes que formaron un grupo para salir adelante como mujeres luchadoras y madres de familia, que desean sobresalir y por ello tratan de fomentar su compañerismo con capacitaciones y encuentros seguidos.
La sra. Herotida es una mujer luchadora que se dedica a la confección de prendas de vestir y bordados varios, ella es de familia pobre y desea que sus hijos no pasen todas las necesidades que ella atravesó y que muchas veces le dificultó alcanzar varias metas que se propuso, por eso Herotida ha trabajado con ahínco, para poder tener muchos clientes fieles y que de alguna manera le brinden un ingreso seguro de dinero para su familia.
Hoy está solicitando el crédito de Kiva para poder comprar aceite para mantener su máquina de coser y comprar más telas con las que pueda trabajar.
texts.en:
The “Santa Librada” committee was formed through the union of various neighbors in the city of Mariano Roque Alonso.

All of the committee members carry out activities of different kinds, but sometimes they carry out joint activities to raise funds for their committee in case of need. 

The members are humble people who formed a group in order to get ahead as hard-working women and mothers who want to improve their lives. For this reason, they try to boost their sense of unity with training sessions and frequent meetings. 

Herotida is a hard-working woman whose business is making clothing and a variety of embroidered items. She comes from a poor family, and she wants to avoid seeing her children suffer from the lack of necessities as she did, which often made it hard for her to reach the goals she set for herself. Because of this, she has worked with great dedication to gain many steady customers and to be able to provide a secure monetary income for her family. 

Today she is requesting the loan from Kiva so that she can buy oil to maintain her sewing machine, and also buy more fabrics to work with.

loans.use: to buy fabrics as well as oil for her sewing machine.

loans.name: Chan

texts.en: Chan A., age 34, is married and resides in Siem Reap province, Cambodia, an area known for Angkorean Temples.  A. is a housewife while her husband is a construction worker, earning an income of about 8 USD per day.  Each month, the family has to spend 30 USD on food and 45 USD on other necessary expenses.  A. is requesting a loan of 1,200 USD to purchase a motorbike for her husband to commute to work.  This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike for her husband to commute to work

loans.name: Sri

texts.en:
Sri K. is a rice farmer in the province of Kompong Cham. She and her husband always help each other to feed their two young kids who are still enrolled in a local school. The couple always uses their own farmland for planting rice, and they are able to use their land to cultivate different kinds of crops at least twice a year. From this rice crop-planting business, they can make around $3.75 a day to cover the family expenses. 

The heavy rainfall is the best sign for growing her crops, but she lacks capital to do so. In order to clear this situation, Sri K. will use her loan to rent a plot of farmland to enlarge her crop, and to purchase seeds, insecticides, and fertilizer for growing it.

loans.use: to rent a plot of farmland to enlarge her crop, and to purchase seeds, insecticides and fertilizer.

loans.name: San Cayetano Group

texts.es:
El comité San Cayetano se formó con la unión de varias vecinas de la comunidad del Asentamiento San Cayetano de la ciudad de San Estanislao (Santaní).
El comité está en el segundo ciclo con 14 integrantes, es un grupo que se destaca en el barrio por ser sus integrantes muy unidas, solidarias y responsables, todas poseen un gran espíritu emprendedor, ya que están al día con sus actividades para demostrar que tienen voluntad y deseos de superación.
La sra. Digna es la presidenta del comité, ella se dedica a la cría de animales, específicamente cerdos en la actualidad, es un negocio que emprendió buscando el bienestar de su familia, son de origen muy humilde y precario, por eso busca constantemente superar la pobreza en la que se encuentran y darles a sus familiares una calidad de vida mucho mejor.
Como desea poder mantener la calidad de los animales que vende para el consumo, solicita el crédito para poder comprar balanceados y medicamentos.
texts.en:
The communal bank San Cayetano was formed by several neighbors in the San Cayetano community in the city of San Estanislao (Santaní).

The group is in its second cycle with 14 members.  It is well known in the neighborhood because its members are united, supportive and responsible and all possess a great enterprising spirit, showing their drive and desire to get ahead in their businesses.

Mrs. Digna is the president of the group.  She raises animals, specifically pigs at this time, and started the business to help her family.  They are from modest, humble beginnings and are constantly to look for ways to get out of the impoverished situation and lead a better lifestyle.

Since she wants to raise quality animals to sell for consumption, she is requesting a loan to buy balanced animal feed and medicine.

loans.use: To buy balanced animal feed and medicine

loans.name: Phan

texts.en: Phan S., age 44, is married and resides in Siem Reap province, Cambodia, an area known for Angkorean Temples.  S. and her husband sell grilled chickens and bread, earning an income of about 5 USD per day.  Each month, the family has to spend 75 USD on food and 15 USD on other necessary expenses.  S. is requesting a loan of 800 USD to purchase cosmetic products for her children to resell.  This will be her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy cosmetic products for her children to resell

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Thirty-nine-year-old Alice K. is married, has four children aged 22, 20, 17 and 13 years, and one additional dependent, her elderly mother who resides with her. In 1996, inspired by friends engaged in the same activity, Alice established her charcoal business as a means of supporting her family. Her business is open from 7am to 7pm daily.

With a good repayment history, Alice is now requesting a new loan to buy bags of charcoal for resale, the additional profits to go toward payment of school fees for her children. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy bags of charcoal for her business.

loans.name: Peoung

texts.en: Peoung P., age 49, is married and resides in Siem Reap province, Cambodia, an area known for Angkorean Temples.  P. is a recycler, earning an income of about 10 USD per day.  Her husband is a road worker, earning an income of 4 USD per day.  Each month, the family has to spend 75 USD on food and 55 USD on other necessary expenses.  P. is requesting a loan of 1,000 USD to purchase a motorbike for her children to commute to work.  This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike for her children to commute to work

loans.name: San Pablo Group

texts.es:
El comité "San Pablo" surgió a través del contacto que tuvo la tesorera con la Fundación Paraguaya. 
Está integrado por 10 señoras emprendedoras, todas ellas son de la misma zona, vecinas, con el crédito que solicitan pretenden aumentar sus negocios y crear nuevas fuentes de ingresos para mejorar sus calidad de vida.
La señora Bernarda R. fue la primera en comunicarse con la asesora de comité, interesada en formar su propio grupo; ella está trabajando como empleada doméstica y tiene por objetivo destinar el crédito para la cría y venta de pollos, es un negocio que quiere emprender, además de llevar a cabo el plan de trabajo grupal para el mejor entendimiento y desempeño del grupo.
Todas son mujeres que necesitan un apoyo económico, por eso confían en Kiva, en sus inversionistas, en que las ayudarán a salir adelante como lo han hecho con otros grupos.
texts.en:
The communal bank "San Pablo" came about through a contact the Paraguaya Foundation's treasurer had.

It is comprised of 10 women entrepreneurs who live in the same area and are neighbors.  With the loan they have requested they plan to increase their businesses and create new sources of income to improve their lifestyles.

Mrs. Bernarda R. was the first one to get in touch with the group's guidance couselor because she was interested in setting up her own group.  She works in house cleaning and wants to use the loan to raise and sell chickens.  It is a business she wants to get started in, and she also wants to set up a group plan to improve understanding and duties within the group.

All are women who need economic help and, therefore, they trust Kiva and the lenders to help them get ahead just like other groups.

loans.use: To buy chickens, medicine and balanced feed

loans.name: Tep

texts.en: Tep B., age 38, is married and resides in Siem Reap province, Cambodia, an area known for Angkorean Temples.  B. is a food seller, earning an income of about 10 USD per day.  Her husband is a boat manufacturer, earning an income of 5 USD per day.  Each month, the family has to spend 75 USD on food and 65 USD on other necessary expenses.  B. is requesting a loan of 600 USD to repair her house. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: to repair her house

loans.name: Chhouy

texts.en:
Chhouy C., 24, is married and resides in Siem Reap province, Cambodia, an area known for Angkorean Temples. 

C. is a watermelon seller, earning an income of about US $3 per day. Her husband is a construction worker, earning an income of US $5 per day. They also have a rice farm as a source of income. Each month, the family has to spend US $60 on food and US $20 on other necessary expenses. 

C. is requesting a loan of US $900 to purchase a mechanical plow to help plow the rice fields. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy a mechanical plow to help plow the rice field.

loans.name: Las Chicas Superpoderosas Group

texts.es:
El comité "Las chicas superpoderosas" es de la zona de San Ignacio, surgió a través de promociones realizadas en el barrio, está integrado por 15 señoras.
Todas ellas se comprometen a cumplir con responsabilidad con sus actividades y con el pago de sus cuotas en caso de acceder al crédito que solicitan y así llegar hasta el nivel máximo del programa.
La señora Maria Bernardina R. se dedica a la venta de chipas (Masa típica de Paraguay hecha a base de queso y almidón), integró el grupo con el propósito de aumentar su actividad, así mismo ella ahora emprenderá la venta, además de la chipa, de empanadas y sopas paraguayas (sólido a base de maíz), para que pueda mejorar sus ingresos y la educación de sus hijos.
Todas las integrantes del comité esperan poder contar con la ayuda de Kiva, pues están esperanzadas en que algún día superarán la pobreza en que se encuentran.
texts.en:
The committee, "Las chicas superpoderosas" (superpowerful girls) is from the area of San Ignacio. It arose as a result of the promotions made in the neighborhood. It is made up of 15 women. All of them promise to do their jobs and to make their payments with responsibility in the event that they get access to the loan they have requested and to achieve the greatest level of the program.

Maria Bernardina R. is dedicated to selling "chipas" (typical Paraguayan dough made from a base of cheese and starch). She formed the group with the purpose of expanding her work. At the same time, she now will undertake the sale of not only chipa, but also empanadas and Paraguayan soups (corn-based) so she can improve her income and the education of her children.

All of the members of the committee hope to be able to count on the help of Kiva since they are hopeful that, one day, they will overcome the poverty in which they find themselves.

loans.use: to purchase starch, cheese and bags of polyethylene, in addition to maize, oil, meats, etc.

loans.name: Chem

texts.en:
Chem C., 54, is married and resides in Siem Reap province, Cambodia, an area known for Angkorean Temples. 

Chem C. is employed to transport fish, earning an income of about US $2.5 per day. Each month, the family has to spend US $50 on food and US $20 on the other necessary expenses. 

Chem C. is requesting a loan of US $1,000 to purchase a motorbike for the children to commute to work. This will be his first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner. C. appears in the photograph with his wife.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike for the children to commute to work

loans.name: Hib

texts.en:
Hib C., 34, is married and resides in Siem Reap province, Cambodia, an area known for Angkorean Temples. 

C. sells duck eggs, earning an income of about US $2.5 per day. Her husband produces wooden furniture, earning an income of US $7 per day. Each month, the family has to spend US $60 on food and US $20 on the other necessary expenses. 

C. is requesting a loan of US $500 to purchase a machine to cut wood for her husband to improve his business. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy a machine to cut wood for her husband's furniture business.

loans.name: Edgar

texts.en:
Edgar B. is from the village of Cabisera 9-11, San Antonio, Ilagan, Isabela. He is 50 years old. Edgar is married and has two adult children. 

To make a living, Edgar owns and operates a general store. Edgar has been engaged in his business for over two years and earns approximately 4,200 PHP a month.

In 2007, Edgar joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Edgar has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. 

Edgar is requesting a new loan of 18,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items such as rice to expand his product offering. This will be the sixth loan taken out by Edgar from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand his business. 

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items such as rice to expand his product offering.

loans.name: Phong

texts.en:
Phong S., 40, is married and resides in Phnom Penh City, Cambodia, an area known for the most populated city in the country. 

Phong S. sells coffee and rents parts of her house to workers at the factory, earning an income of about US $5 per day. Her husband is a civil servant, earning an income of US $5 per day. Each month, the family has to spend US $112 on food and US $45 on the other necessary expenses. 

Phong S. is requesting a loan of US $1,000 to purchase construction materials to build more rooms for rent. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy construction materials to build more rooms for rent.

loans.name: Big

texts.en: Big T., 49, is married and resides in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for Pre-angkorean temples. T. sells bananas, earning an income of about USD 3 per day, while her husband, a carpenter, earns USD 5 per day. Each month, the family has to spend USD 45 on food and USD 30 on the other necessary expenses. T. is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to purchase a motorbike for the children to commute to work. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike for the children to commute to work

loans.name: Chea

texts.en:
Chea T., 48, is married and resides in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for Pre-angkorean temples. Chea sells hand-made brooms, earning an income of about USD 4 per day, while her husband, a motor-taxi driver, earns USD 4 per day. Each month, the family has to spend USD 45 on food and USD 30 on the other necessary expenses.

Chea is requesting a loan of USD 500 to purchase a new motorbike for her husband to operate his business more efficiently. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike for her husband

loans.name: Hang's Group

texts.en:
Hang T. N. is 41 years old with 2 children. She is a group leader of a 5 member group. All members have different types of businesses. Ms. Hang is a widower so it is quiet difficult for her to manage family life. She not only does farming such as raising pigs but also works as a constructor. Every month, she can earn a total income of 3,000,000 Vietnamese dong.  Being a client of our credit program since 2006, she has use loans very effectively to expand her farming. She wants to borrow 7,630,000 Vietnamese dong to buy more food for pigs.

Lien T. D. is 35 years old with 2 children. She runs a tailoring shop at her house. She wants a loan of 6,322,000 Vietnamese dong to buy more clothes.

Su T. H. is 48 years old with 2 children. She grows rice and vegetables in a paddy of 4,500 square meters. She wants a loan of 7,630,000 Vietnamese dong to buy a more seeds and fertilizer.

Mai  T. N. is 41 years old with 2 children. She runs a small restaurant that serves breakfast. She needs a loan of 6,322,000 Vietnamese dong to buy 7 sets of tables and chairs.

Dong T. T. is 40 years old. She is a farmer who grows rice and vegetables to sell in a local market. She is requesting a loan of 7,630,000 Vietnamese dong to buy fertilizer.

loans.use: to buy more food for pigs

loans.name: Celia

texts.en:
Celia B. is from the village of Cabisera 9-11, San Antonio, Ilagan, Isabela. She is 40 years old. Celia is married and has two school-aged children. 

Celia raises pigs for fattening and sale to finance the education of their children and the daily needs of her family. Celia has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 4,500 PHP whenever she sells her raised animals.

In 2007, Celia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Celia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. 

Celia is requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise. This will be the sixth loan taken out by Celia from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase baby livestock to raise.

loans.name: Huch

texts.en:
Huch C., 32, is married and resides in Takeo province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorean temples. 

Huch C. sells groceries, earning an income of about US $3 per day. Her husband is a motor-taxi driver, earning an income of US $4 per day. Each month, the family has to spend US $45 on food and US $30 on the other necessary expenses. 

C. is requesting a loan of US $1,200 to purchase a new motorbike for her children to commute to work. This will be her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike for the children to commute to work

loans.name: Huyen's Group

texts.en:
Huyen T. Pham is 36 years old. She lives with her with her family in Dong hoi commune. Ms Huyen has opened a butchery and cookie shop at her house. Every day, this shop provides her with a profit of 200,000 Vietnamese dong that helps her to manage her family life. She participates in our credit program with the hope of having more money to buy more kinds of sweet products to expand her shop and attract more customers. She needs a loan of 5,014,000 Vietnamese dong. She thinks this kind of loan is very suitabL. with her business.

Mai T. H. L. is 45 children. She is doing a variety of farming such as growing rice, raising fish and pigs for meat. She needs a loan of 5,014,000 Vietnamese dong to buy food for them.

Nga T. B. is 46 year old with 2 children. She is raising 200 chickens for meat. She is requesting a loan of 5,014,000 Vietnamese dong to buy food for them.

Binh T. N. is 35 years old with 2 children. She sells ready, cooked food in the local market. Now she needs a loan of 5,014,000 Vietnamese dong to buy materials.

L. T. N. is 43 years old with 1 child. She sells aquatic products wholesaL.. She needs to have a loan of 5,014,000 Vietnamese dong to buy more products

loans.name: Gulsaara's Group

texts.en:
Gulsaara S., the treasurer of this group, is 39 and lives in Tashkomur – a small mining town in the south of Kyrgyzstan. Unfortunately, she is a widow and has two daughters, both of whom study at school.

In order to earn money, Gulsaara takes orders and sews and sells Kyrgyz national blankets, cloth and dressmaking supplies. She is also engaged in livestock breeding; reselling livestock animals after fattening them, she earns an additional 1500 soms per month. With money received from the loan, Gulsaara wants to purchase more livestock, and dreams of building a big house for her daughters in the future.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase livestock.

loans.name: Ganbold

texts.en:
Mr. Ganbold is a 49-year-old carpenter. He has been running a furniture making business since 2006. He lives with his wife and only son in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. His wife works as a chef in a cafeteria. 

Ganbold's family lives in a house which he built a few years ago. Ganbold uses his garage as a workshop and he employs two more carpenters. He produces different home furniture such as beds, sofas, wardrobes, shelves, chairs and so on per customer order. His products are in high demand, especially furniture for gers, which are traditional Mongolian nomadic tents. He gets enough orders to complete. He also sells some of his products at Narantuul, the biggest outdoor market in Ulaanbaatar city. 

This loan Ganbold is asking for will be used to replenish some of his tools and to stock more materials such as wood, planks, metal sheets, and other necessary things to make furniture.

loans.use: to buy a new sewing machine

loans.name: Nurjan's Group

texts.en:
Nurjan A. is the leader of this group. She is 47 and divorced. She has raised a son, 22, who works as a security guard and studies at a university away from home. Nurjan works in the hospital as an X-ray technician. In order to earn additional money she breeds livestock. She started this activity two years ago with the initial investment of 10,000 soms. With money received from the loan Nurjan wants to purchase three sheep in order to increase the number of livestock she owns. In the near future the family is planning to celebrate her son’s wedding.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. 

To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase three sheep

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen is 49 years old and married with three children. She is engaged in farming. She grows rice and corn on her land. Helen works hard to grow her business. She plans to use her loan to purchase seeds and fertilizers and to pay for labor.

In the future, Helen hopes for her family's living conditions to improve.

loans.use: to purchase seeds and fertilizers and to pay for labor

loans.name: Pol

texts.en:
Pol S., 58, resides in Prey Veng province, Cambodia, an area known as one of the largest rice producing regions in Cambodia. 

S. is a farmer and a grocery seller, earning an income of $7 US per day. Two of her children are employed at the factory, earning an income of $3 each per day. Each month, the family has to spend $20 on food and $35 on the other necessary expenses. 

S. is requesting a loan of $1000 to purchase groceries to sell. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy groceries to resell

loans.name: Ronaldo

texts.en:
Ronaldo C. is from the village of Estrada, Quezon, Isabela. He is 29 years old. Ronaldo is married and has one infant child. Ronaldo raises pigs for breeding. As a beginner in the business he only earns 3500 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. 

In 2011, Ronaldo joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to do business. Ronaldo is requesting a  loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Ronaldo from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it. 

About ASKI: 

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fishermen and small entrepreneurs. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed & other supplies

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine is 48 years old and married with three children. Her oldest child is 29 years old.

Josephine is a farmer working in Banga, South Cotabato. She grows rice and corn. Josephine has prepared her land for planting. She applied for a loan so she could purchase fertilizers, and corn and rice seeds. Josephine is hopeful that this loan will help increase her harvest.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers, and corn and rice seeds

loans.name: Paquito

texts.en:
Paquito S. is from the village of Kinangay Norte, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. He is 60 years old. Paquito is married and has three adult children. Paquito owns and operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Paquito has been engaged in his business for over three years and earns approximately 20,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. 

In 2008, Paquito joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to do business. Paquito has successfully repaid a previous loan from GDMPC. Paquito is requesting a new loan of 30,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products like canned goods, noodles, sugar and coffee. This loan will be the eighth loan taken out by Paquito from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. 

About GDMPC: 

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has seven branches covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fishermen and small entrepreneurs. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products such as canned goods, noodles. sugar and coffee

loans.name: Vui

texts.en: Vui T. H. is 53 years old with 3 children.  Two of them are of working age. She is a farmer.  Her main activity is growing rice and vegetables in  a paddy of 5,600 square meters.  All  products after harvest are used to support her family's diet.  Her business started a long time ago and it developed more when she received loans from our credit program.  Currently, she wants a loan of 8,066,000 Vietnamese dong to buy fertilizer and some pesticide.

loans.use: to buy  fertilizer and some pesticide.

loans.name: Nourn

texts.en:
Nourn C., 35, resides in Siem Reap province, Cambodia, an area known for Angkorean temples. C. sells vegetables, earning an income of $10 US per day. Her husband is a taxi driver, earning an income of $5 per day. Each month, the family has to spend $60 on food and $35 on other necessary expenses. 

C. is requesting a loan of $300 to purchase a machine to harvest rice. This will be her first from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy a machine to harvest rice

loans.name: Tep

texts.en: Tep S., 29, resides in Siem Reap province, Cambodia, an area known for Angkorean temples. S. is a housewife while her husband produces wooden boats, earning an income of $5 US per day. Each month, the family has to spend $60 on food and $35 on other necessary expenses. S. is requesting a loan of $300 to purchase a motorbike for the family's use. This will be her first from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike for the family's use

loans.name: Muhabbathan's Group

texts.en:
Muhabbathan N. is a member of this group. She is 40 and unfortunately, she is a widow. She is raising three children: two sons and a daughter.  The sons attend school and the daughter is too young to attend. Muhabbathan works as a biology teacher at school. She has been working in that school for 18 years. Her monthly salary is 5,550 KGS. She applied for the loan because she needs some money to cover family expenses. In the future, she wants to provide her children a good education.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to cover family expenses

loans.name: Narangerel

texts.en:
Narangerel is 54 years old and lives with her husband and youngest daughter in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent, in Sansar area, Ulaanbaatar, capital city of Mongolia. Her older children all live and work on their own. 

Narangerel manages a Mongolian traditional clothes-making business in Ulaanbaatar city. She started her business in 2002 with the help of her younger daughter, who is 29 years old. She makes a variety of stylish and colorful Mongolian traditional coats called Deel. Her business becomes quite profitable during national holidays, including Tsagaan sar and Naadam. 

Narangerel is planning to operate a knitted clothing business in addition to her traditional clothing business. She is a polite woman who possesses a good personality. She says, "I want my younger daughter to be happy and be married to nice man." Narangerel is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to purchase a sewing machine and some yarn in order to start her knitted clothing business.

loans.use: to purchase a sewing machine

loans.name: Amanjol

texts.en: Amanjol is 29 years old and lives with his wife and daughter in a house in Bayan-Ulgii province, Mongolia. His wife is a photographer with a monthly salary of 100,000 MNT. Amanjol is planning to open his own tire repair business in his town. He used to operate a meat-trading business with his older sister for 3 years. Since 2007, he began working at his older brother's auto repair shop for a monthly salary of 150,000 MNT. At his brother's shop, he learns to fix car parts and has particularly specialized in tire repair. Now Amanjol is building a small workshop where he can start his own business of tire repair. He is an honest man who is planning to open his own auto repair business someday. He is requesting a 2,500,000 MNT loan to purchase construction materials from China for his workshop.

loans.use: to purchase construction materials to build a new business

loans.name: Tsendjargal

texts.en:
Mr. Tsendjargal, 24 years old, lives with his wife and only son in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. His son attends a kindergarten. Tsendjargal’s wife, Tumendolgor, 24, is an orphan and she carries the duty to look after her three younger sisters.

Tsendjargal runs a shoe retail business in the Narantuul, the biggest outdoor market in Ulaanbaatar. He works all year round and it is very hard to stay outdoors all day long, especially in the winter, because the average winter day temperature is minus 25 degrees Celsius. He has been running this business for 5 years has gained a lot of experience in the shoe sale market. Tsendjargal is planning to expand his business by enlarging his stall and increasing his working capital. Therefore, he needs to rent one more neighboring stall and to fill it with shoe products. He will use this loan to buy more summer shoes to increase his inventory and to pay for his first stall rental payment.

loans.use: To buy more shoes for the summer season and to enlarge his stall.

loans.name: Bolasbai

texts.en: Bolasbai is 43 years old and lives with his wife and daughter in a house in the Bayan-Ulgii province of Mongolia. His daughter, age 13, attends a local secondary school. Bolasbai manages a grocery business with the help of his wife. He started his business in 2003 and has since worked hard to provide goods and services that could be of great value to innumerable customers. Through his diligent work, he has built a strong customer base and made his grocery shop well-known. He has also managed to pay his daughter's education expenses. Bolasbai is an honest man who attributes his success to his good accounting skills. He says, "I want to own a big trading center one day." He is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan to purchase more inventory in order to increase his business sales.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory.

loans.name: Chanthy

texts.en:
Mrs. Chanthy R. and her husband, Sophorn Doem, live on Koh Dach Island in the Mekong River, about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh. They have two sons and two daughters; one is married and lives separately, one sells ice cream in the village and the other two attend school. 

Mrs. Chanthy R. is a weaver and her husband is a horse cart driver. His horse is now old and doesn't seem strong enough to work, so he wants to buy another horse as a replacement. Chanthy is asking for a loan of $600 to help her husband buy a new horse.

loans.use: To purchase a horse for her husband’s horse cart driving business.

loans.name: Avish

texts.en:
H. is 50 years old and lives with her husband and three daughters in a house in Bayan-Ulgii province, Mongolia. Her older two daughters are students and the younger one attends a local secondary school.

H. manages a shoemaking business in her town. She started her business in 2003 after working as a shoemaker in a public factory for several years. When the factory had to close its doors, H. became unemployed and began wondering what to do next to support her family. She then realized that starting a shoemaking business would be the only solution to her situation.

H. now makes a variety of shoes ranging from sizes 13 to 42. Her shoes are well-known amongst her customers for their quality and comfort. H. sells her shoes at reasonable prices, 6,000 to 60,000 MNT, which are affordable to almost everyone. She makes a net profit of 50-60% from one pair of shoes. H. is a polite woman with lots of good character. She says, “All I want is to get my children educated so they can work at any company they want to." She is requesting a 600,000 MNT loan to purchase leather, glue and some yarn for her business.

loans.use: To purchase leather, glue and some yarn.

loans.name: Hanifan's Group

texts.en:
Hanifan lives in Faisalabad which is Pakistan’s third largest city and known for its textile industry. She resides there in a 2-room brick house with her family in the area of Ghulamabad. She moved here many years ago. 

She is 54 years old and married to G. R.. She has four children: two sons and two daughters. Her elder son works in a factory while the younger one stays at home. From the financial support of her elder son, Hanifan is able to send her two daughters to school. 

Her husband operates a construction supply business while Hanifan makes gloves. She receives orders from different factories and shops and fills the orders to earn income for the family.  She is a very responsible person; as a wife she takes care of her family and manages her household responsibilities very well. 

Hanifan has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah to buy a new machine which will help her make gloves in larger quantity in a shorter period of time and complete the orders on time to generate good income. 

She is a new loan user and this is her first loan application with Asasah.  

Note: In the photo, the lady raising her hand is Hanifan.

loans.use: To buy a new machine for glove-making business.

loans.name: Dosmuhan

texts.en:
Dosmuhan is 34 years old and lives with his wife and three children in a ger, a Mongolian traditional nomadic housing tent, in Bayan-Ulgii province, Mongolia. Dosmuhan's older son attends a local secondary school and his younger two children go to a kindergarten.

Dosmuhan manages a clothing sales business in his town. He started his business 2 years ago with his wife's help. They used to operate a grocery business which wasn’t profitable enough to feed their family. So they decided to open a clothing sales business based on serious market research. Dosmuhan bought a booth valued at 1,000,000 MNT in order to start the business and with only 2 years of operation, he managed to stabilize his business and build a good relationship both with his customers and suppliers. He is a good man who possesses lots of great character. He says, "I want to own my store in the future." Dosmuhan is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan to purchase more collections of clothes from China.

loans.use: To purchase more collections of clothes.

loans.name: Galina's Group

texts.en:
Galina J. leads this three-person loan group and lives in Nookat, a town in the Osh region. She is married and has two sons, one of whom breeds cattle for a living while the other is busy completing his schooling. Galina has made a living as a nurse since 1983 and earns 500 soms a month. Recently she bought some land and began building a house on it for her sons to live in. She is applying for this loan to buy building materials for the house, which she hopes will soon be ready for her sons to move into.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to buy building materials for a new house

loans.name: Erkin

texts.en:
Erkin is 48 years old and lives with his wife and three children in a house in Bayan-Ulgii province, Mongolia. His older two children attend college and the younger one is a student. 

Erkin manages a shoe repair business in his town. He started his business in 2000 in a rented booth at a trading center. He used to rent his booth with another shoe repairer but his business became quite successful, which allowed him to rent his booth on his own. Erkin repairs one pair of shoes at a price of 1,000-4,000 MNT and gains a net profit of 50%. He is very good at attracting customers with his polite communication skills. His business is developing and improving day by day. Erkin is planning to have new and advanced equipment in the near future. He is an honest man who says, "All I want is to get my children educated." Erkin is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan to buy his rented booth and to purchase some materials for his business.

loans.use: to buy his rented booth and to purchase some materials for his business.

loans.name: Ti

texts.en: Ti T., 41, resides in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia, an area known for its rubber plantations. T. raises pigs to sell, earning an income of USD 5 per day. Her husband grows yams to sell, earning an income of USD 5 per day. Each month, the family spends USD 40 on food and USD 35 on other necessary expenses. T. is requesting a loan of USD 1,000 to purchase pigs to raise and to build a place to grow mushrooms. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy pigs and to build a place to grow mushrooms.

loans.name: Atina

texts.en: Atina is 34 years old and lives with her husband and three sons in a ger, a traditional Mongolian tent, in Bayan-Ulgii province. Her oldest son, age 10, attends a local secondary school while her younger two sons, who are 4 and 5, go to a kindergarten. Her husband is an electrical worker who helps ensure the safety of plants operated by the Power Network Division. Atina makes a living managing a grocery in her town. She started her business two years ago and is now very experienced in selling food from assorted places and cultures, especially a wide range of  fruits and vegetables. She is very good at attracting customers and attributes her business success to good decision-making skills. She says, "I want to expand my business and would also truly love to improve living conditions of my family." She is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to buy candies, biscuits and juice to sell to her customers.

loans.use: To buy candies, biscuits and juice to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Lim

texts.en: Lim K., 32, lives in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia, an area known for rubber plantations. She is a housewife while her husband works in construction, earning $7 a day. Each month, the family spends $75 on food and $35 on other necessities. She is applying for a loan of $500 to buy rubber trees, which she plans to grow and harvest. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long-time Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy rubber trees to grow

loans.name: Erlan

texts.en: Erlan is 23 years old and lives with his mother and brothers in a house in Bayan-Ulgii province, Mongolia. Erlan learned to drive a car from his father when he was a teenager and began using this skill to work in transportation in 2009. He makes a living carrying coal from the countryside to customers who live in the city. Sometimes he also helps his older brother. Elram drives 300 km per delivery, a trip which can be quite strenuous and requires lots of patience and hard work. He is a diligent man who says, "I would like to have my own house in the near future." He is applying for a loan for 3,000,000 MNT loan to buy a truck for his older brother and four new tires for his own truck.

loans.use: buy a truck for his brother and four tires for his own truck

loans.name: Gennadyi

texts.en:
Gennadyi is married and has two teenage sons. He lives in the town of Kamenka, where he makes living selling souvenirs, various small products for the home, office supplies, plastic bags and other retail items. Gennadyi has been in this business for 10 years and currently has an inventory worth 70,000 Grivnyas. His net profit comes to about 6,000 Grivnyas a month. 

Gennadyi has made good use of two previous microloans and found them a very effective way to increase the success of his business. Now he is applying for a loan of 20,000 Grivnyas to buy parts for bicycles because selling these items in spring makes a good business sense. He is hoping to generate extra income this season so that he can continue to grow his small business.

loans.use: to purchase parts for bicycles

loans.name: Heang

texts.en:
Heang S. is a 33-year-old farmer who lives in Kompong Cham province. She and her husband have been working together in the farming business for many years.  They have two children. 

On average, they can earn about $4 a day to cover the family’s needs. In order to increase the family's income, Heang S. has applied for a loan to buy a used motorcycle which her husband will use to start a motor taxi service.

loans.use: to buy a used motorcycle which her husband will use to start a motor taxi service.

loans.name: Yen

texts.en:
Yen Y., 36, resides in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia, an area known for its rubber plantations. Y. is a housewife while her husband is employed at a furniture selling shop, earning an income of 6 USD per day. Each month, the family has to spend 85 USD on food and 35 USD on the other necessary expenses.

This will be Y.’s first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner. She is requesting a loan of 1200 USD to repair her house.

loans.use: To repair her house

loans.name: Miech

texts.en:
Miech S., 54 years old, is a humble villager living in the middle of Cambodia in its capital, Phnom Penh. She is married and blessed with six children.  One of her children is single and still living with her under her care while the other five are already married and living in their own houses.

To earn a living, Miech S. and her husband have been cultivating rice crops on land that  has belonged to them for many years.  Miech S. and her husband are seeking a loan to buy two cows that they will rent out to farmers for additional income. The cows can also be used for breeding so the couple can also raise their offspring.

loans.use: to buy two cows that can be rented out to farmers for additional income.

loans.name: Nabatkan Toktokueva's Group

texts.en:
Nabatkan T. is the leader of this group. She is 52 and married to a farmer. Together they are bringing up a fifteen-year-old son who studies at school. In order to earn money the family farms. Nabatkan is also engaged in livestock breeding. She resells livestock animals after fattening them up to get a higher price. In this way she earns 3000 KGS per month.

These profits made it possible for her to purchase a TV and improve the family’s living conditions. With money received from the loan Nabatkan wants to purchase more livestock for breeding.

About Mol Bulak Finance (MBF):

This loan is being presented by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious, socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of its “3-Ps” concept: People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow larger) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year.

To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team—Supporters of Kyrgyzstan—at: http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase more livestock

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
Nancy lives in the town of Banga, South Cotabato with her family. She is engaged in farming and hog-raising businesses. She tills her land for planting rice crops. She also grows vegetables. Nancy raises her pigs in her backyard. Nancy sells her harvest and grown pigs to the market.

Nancy's loan will be used to purchase fertilizers and piglets.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and piglets

loans.name: Siddiqan's Group

texts.en:
Siddiqan comes from Faisalabad which is Pakistan’s third largest city and famous for its textile industry. She has lived there in a 2-room brick house with her husband and children in the area of Ghulamabad for past 20 years. 

She is 45 years old and married to F. A. who operates a loading/unloading business. He works very hard to fulfill the basic needs of the family. Siddiqan’s eldest son operates a clothes-pressing business while the next two are daily wage laborers. From the financial support of their sons, Siddiqan is able to send her only daughter to school. She is studying in class 7. 

Siddiqan herself is a housewife who stays at home and does her household responsibilities.  She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the improvement of her son’s pressing business. Using the loan, he will buy another iron and hire an assistant which will help him to perform well in his business and fulfills his customers' order on time. 

Siddiqan is hopeful that investing loan money in her son’s business will be a good step towards the future growth of his business. She is a new loan user of Asasah and this is her first loan application to Asasah. 

Note: In the photo, the lady raising her hand is Siddiqan.

loans.use: To buy another iron and hire an assistant for clothes-pressing  business.

loans.name: Raul

texts.en:
Raul is a farmer from Banga, South Cotabato. He tills his land for planting rice and corn crops. Raul sells his harvest to his town's market. Raul is also a driver. He said that the additional income from driving helps with his family's daily needs.

Raul's loan will be used to purchase seeds and fertilizers. He hopes that his farm will grow.

loans.use: to purchase seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Mahmoud

texts.en:
Mahmoud K. is an ambitious young man who started his own business three years ago. He sells frozen chicken, other meat, vegetables, and yogurt at his shop. He has been working for three years now and was able to add more refrigerators from the profit he made through these years.

In order to cover all of the local area’s needs in Al Mafraq where he lives, Mahmoud wants to add more products to sell such as oil and other food products, in other words he wants to turn the shop into a mini-market. To be able to do that, he applied for this loan so he can buy his mini-market supplies and start developing his business

loans.use: To add more variety to the  products he sells.

loans.name: Nely's Group

texts.en:
Nely is from the village of Calaocan, Angadanan, Isabela. She is 44 years old and single. Nely is the group leader of a 9-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

To make a living, Nely owns and operates a general store selling food and daily use products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 3500 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2011, Nely joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional groceries to sell. 

Nely is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP to purchase groceries like canned goods, noodles, coffee, sugar and milk. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase groceries like canned goods, noodles, coffee, sugar and milk

loans.name: Taing

texts.en:
The rice-planting business is the most popular occupation for Cambodian people who live in the countryside. Taing S. earns a living by cultivating rice crops. She was blessed with seven children, two of whom are working on the farm. Another source of family income is her husband’s business.  He is a horse cart driver in and around the community. 

Taing S.’s house is too small and she really wants to enlarge the size of her home, but she doesn’t have enough funds. To overcome this obstacle, Taing S. would like to request a loan to purchase some housing materials to build a new house.

loans.use: to purchase some housing materials for  to build a new house.

loans.name: Harutyun

texts.en:
Harutyun P. is 49 years old and lives in Vanadzor city. He is married and has three children — two daughters and a son. His daughters are already married and live separately, and his son is in school. 

For about 16 years Harutyun has been engaged in trading men and women clothing and sleepwear at the Vanadzor clothes fair. His wife stays at home and keeps the house.

Harutyun needs a 1,000,000 AMD loan to buy spring and summer clothes to resell.  This is Harutyun’s third loan from Kiva and his 15th loan from Nor Horizon, and he has never been late with his repayments.

loans.use: to buy spring and summer clothes to resell

loans.name: Manuel's Group

texts.en:
Manuel N. is from the village of Lalog 2, Luna, Isabela. He is 43 years old. Manuel is the group leader of a 5-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Manuel is married and has 1 school-aged child. To make a living, Manuel owns & operates a business providing plumbing repairs in the local community. Manuel has been engaged in his business for over 10 years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Manuel joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Manuel has successfully repaid a previous loan of 9000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase materials needed to provide service. 

Manuel is requesting a new loan of 12000 PHP which will be used to purchase more materials needed, such as pipes. This loan will be his 5th loan from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve/expand his business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase materials needed for his plumbing business

loans.name: Ra'eqa

texts.en:
Ra’eqa A. K., who has creative and artistic ideas, decided to learn from her husband’s previous experience in carpet weaving and spinning, and combine it with her creative skill to start their own business five years ago.

Ra’eqa started to create beautiful carpet designs and work with her husband in turning those designs into actual carpets in many sizes and sell them. Their carpets now are known in their city Zarqa, 

Ra’eqa has applied for this loan to be able to open their own shop since they are now working at their house. In the future their ambition is to open other branches so they can reach all Jordanian cities.

loans.use: To open their own shop for carpet-weaving and spinning.

loans.name: Adelanta's Group

texts.en:
Adelanta C. is from the village of Research Minante 1, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 59 years old. Adelanta is the group leader of a 6-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Adelanta is married and has 5 adult children. To make a living, Adelanta owns & operates a general store selling food & daily use products in the local community. Adelanta has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 19000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2006, Adelanta joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Adelanta has successfully repaid a previous loan of 30000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional groceries to sell. 

Adelanta is requesting a new loan of 40000 PHP to purchase more groceries inventory to sell. This will be her 11th loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Vergilia

texts.en:
Vergilia is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a fishing and fish vending business in the Philippines.  She has been in this business for 20 years. Vergilia also earns income from selling vegetables.  She has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. 

Vergilila is borrowing PHP 29000 through NWTF to purchase materials needed to repair her fishing boat.  She dreams of saving money to expand her business in the future.

loans.use: purchase materials needed to repair her fishing boat

loans.name: Ven

texts.en: Ven S. is 49 years old and is a widow.  She works as a professional tailor, making US$3 each day in the Kampong Chhnang province. She has six children living at home. Her husband, Hang Rorn, makes approximately US$2.50 every day. Ven S. would like a loan of US$500 to finish constructing her house.

loans.use: to finish constructing her house

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
As a married parent of 2 children, Erlinda works hard to support her family.  She has a fish vending business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from a sari sari store.  Erlinda is borrowing PHP 25000 through NWTF to buy an additional box of fish to sell in her fish vending business.

Erlinda has been sustaining her business activities through her past 16 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream of saving money to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more fish to sell

loans.name: Ma

texts.en:
This photograph shows Ma S. H., who resides in the province of Siem Reap. Ma S. H. and her husband make their living by working as local farmers in the village. In addition, her husband sells coal for extra income. This couple has four children: two are married and live separately and the others are single. Two of them are employed as workers in Thailand. 

In the past, Ma S. H. hired the neighbor’s cow to alleviate the chore of plowing the farmland. She hopes to buy her own cow and that is why she is applying for a loan from Kiva.

loans.use: to buy a cow to plow her farmland.

loans.name: Chon

texts.en: Chon S., 52, is married and has three children living at home.  She lives in the Kampong Chhnang province.  Since 2000, she has been selling meat and wine from home and is able to make about US$5 in profit each day. Her husband is a construction worker, making typically US$2 per day. Chon S. is asking for a loan of US$1000 to purchase wood, cement and other materials to complete the construction of her home.

loans.use: to complete the construction of her home

loans.name: Prak

texts.en: Prak P. is 66 years old and is a widow.  She lives with two of her children in Kampong Chhnang province. She sells fried bananas from home, earning US$1 per day. She is also receives support from two of her children who are employed in garment factories.  Prak P. needs a loan of US$1200 to fix her leaking roof and broken wood ladder.

loans.use: fix her leaking roof and broken wood ladder

loans.name: Evelyn's Group

texts.en:
Evelyn M. is from the village of Malalinta. She is 43 years old. Evelyn is the group leader of a 6-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Evelyn M.'s Group.

Evelyn is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Evelyn owns & operates a general store selling a variety of different products to the local community. Evelyn has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Evelyn joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 18,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. 

Evelyn is requesting a new loan of 20000 PHP to purchase more groceries inventory to sell. This will be her 7th loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay tuition fees for her children. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional groceries to sell

loans.name: Avazmurod

texts.ru: Содиков Авазмурод проживает в городе Турсунзаде. Ему 41 год. Он женат, имеет одного ребенка. Его жена домохозяйка. Сам Авазмурод имеет высшее педагогическое образование. Он 18 лет как работает учителем в средней школе. Кроме того он занимается растениеводством. В основном он выращивает овощи для продажи. Этим видом деятельности занимается более 20 лет. Кредит берет для закупа семян.
texts.en: Avazmurod S. lives in the town of Tursun-zoda. He is 41 years old. He is married and has one child. His wife is a homemaker. Avazmurod has higher pedagogical education. He has been working as a school teacher for eighteen years. He also does agriculture. He mainly grows vegetables for resale. He has been in this business for more than twenty years. He is taking out the loan to buy seeds.

loans.use: to buy seeds

loans.name: Tob

texts.en: Tob S., 38 and living with her husband in Kampong Chhnang Province, sells rice and noodles, typically making US$7 per day, while her husband, a construction worker who builds houses, earns on average US$2 each day. Tob S. is requesting a loan of US$1200 for two purposes: she will use half  to invest in her current business of selling rice and noodle and the rest  to finish her construction.

loans.use: to expand her business of selling rice and noodle and to finish her construction

loans.name: Kem

texts.en: Kem T., 42, is a soldier who lives with his wife and three children in Kampong Chhnang Province. He has been a soldier since 1987, and is able to make US$2 per day. His wife stays at home selling meatballs and cake, earning US$2.50 per day. Kem T. would like to take out a loan of US$700 to open another business. She raises about US$200 chickens and purchase chicken feed as well.

loans.use: to raise chickens

loans.name: Juvelyn

texts.en:
Juvelyn is a 30-year-old married mother of two children, one of whom is currently in school. Juvelyn works very hard to provide for them by running a sari-sari store in the Philippines. In business for six years selling a variety of items such as coffee, cream, sugar, etc., she is now requesting a PHP 25000 loan through NWTF to buy more items to sell such as shampoo and groceries in her store.

In the future Juvelyn would like to save enough money to send her child to college.

loans.use: to buy additional items to sell in her general store.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Eam

texts.en: Eam R. is 34 years old and sells vegetables in the Kampong Chnang province. Her business has been around for about four years, and she makes US $1.50 every day. Her husband is a truck driver, earning US $3 per day. This couple has three school-age children living at home to support. Eam R. is asking for a loan of US $700 to raise about US $200 in chickens and purchase food for the chickens as well.

loans.use: to raise chickens

loans.name: Mary Grace

texts.en: Mary Grace is from the village of Upper Langcangan, Oroquieta City. She is 32 years old. Mary Grace is married and has three adult children. Mary Grace owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 6,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. Mary Grace is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase products for her general store. This loan will be her 10th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it. About PMPC Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase products for her general store

loans.name: Hing

texts.en: Hing L., 36, resides in Kampong Cham Province, Cambodia, an area known for rubber plantations. L. sells groceries, earning an income of $5 USD per day. Her husband is a construction foreman, earning an income of $7 USD per day. Each month, the family has to spend $85 USD on food and $35 USD on other necessary expenses.
